characters: 42A INT, IRONING AND SEWING ROOM. NIGHT.
INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. EVE

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMAN
dialogues.text: Just start, you filthy heap of scrap.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She’ll hear you one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t care if she does.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t you just? The motor catches and he stands. While the passenger seat enclosed, the front, driving seat is open to the weather. places a basket with a thermos glass and a sealed, tin sa container on the rear seat. As she does so, it begins to

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER, (VO)
dialogues.text: Mary? Merriman? Are you ready? With a final check, she looks up to where a butler in a b morning coat waits.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr Burkett. We can hardly hear his “Everything's ready, milady,” nor see the face behind the veil of the figure who hurries do steps. This is Constance, Countess of Trentham. Muffled i against the cold, she hurries into the waiting vehicle. The titles run over the following sequence. EXT. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY. Merriman drives. Mary sits silently next to him, huddling her coat. Unlike the passenger, the servants, in the roof front seat, are exposed to the rain. INT. CONSTANCE’S CAR. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY. Gloved hands try lazily to open the thermos, give up imme and reach for the polished brass speaking tube. The veile indistinct mouth gives some instructions.  EXT. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY. They pull over and the dripping maid gets out as a large stops. It is bright with shining chrome. It looks like To next to the Daimler’s Yesterday. A man in the front passe seat looks out helpfully. He speaks in a Californian acce

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Do you need any help? Are you O.K.? The door is open now and, behind the maid, the indistinct passenger speaks.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Am I what?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We‘re quite all right. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Excuse me but.. is that.. Lady Trentham? Constance does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't remember me.. I’m William McCordle‘s cousin. Ivor Novello. At this Mary gasps in recognition but Constance merely no

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: May I present a friend of mine from California, Morris Weissman? And — Having indicated the American on the passenger side in fr has turned to a very handsome young man sitting behind bu second thoughts, he breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was wondering if we were all headed in the same direction...

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I dare say we might be.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Well.. if you’re sure you don’t need any help.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary has opened the folding table for the refreshments. T other car drives away.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Was that really Ivor Novello?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Could we get on before I freeze to death? The maid shuts the car door, climbs in and the journey continues. The credits end. EXT, GOSFORD PARK. DAY. The great house stands confidently in its park, proclaimi social pre-eminence. As the car continues down the drive, catches the attention of a beautiful woman who is canteri her horse, Topaz. She wears jodphurs and a loosely tied n scarf over her hacking jacket. This is Lady Sylvia McCord daughter of an earl and doyenne of Gosford. She digs in h heels and heads for the house. As she arrives at the front steps, the Novello car is mov away to the side and Novello himself, with his companion, being shepherded inside by the butler, Jennings. A footma (Arthur) holds an umbrella. With them is the owner of all surveys, Sir William McCordle, bart, a rich parvenu and p it. In his arms he holds a wiry unattractive terrier The of Constance makes him turn back.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Constance, Welcome. The visitor nods as Sylvia jumps down from her horse, tos the reins back over its head. She gives her aunt a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: If he has to call me by my christian name, why can’t he make it “Aunt Constance”? I’m not the upstairs maid.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You know what he's like.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I see he's still got that vile dog.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It's so typical. The ones you hate live forever. Have you had a horrid journey?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Fairly horrid.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You must be frozen. Come and have some tea, Mary eyes the standing horse warily. With a snort, it sha head and, rather gingerly, she stretches out her hand to the reins under the animal’s chin. At once it starts to f and plunge. Sylvia looks across.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave him alone. He knows what to do. The embarrassed maid drops the reins as a groom appears a leads the docile horse away. Mary, of course, does not kn to do. Sylvia and her aunt start up the steps but we do not foll they move off camera. Jennings steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Take the car round the back to unload it. The car starts up and heads towards the side of the house Still, Mary waits. Jennings looks over to the maid as he starts to reclimb the front steps

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'd better follow him. Mrs Wilson‘11 look after you. A lone figure, she trudges off through the puddles, clutc the dressing case, as the car carrying the Stockbridge pa sweeps up to the front. INT. KITCHEN CORRIDOR. DAY. Chaos reigns. Servants duck past the piled up trunks and Valets and maids (Barnes and Sarah, joined later by Renee Robert) struggle to check that none of their luggage has the wrong rooms. Surveying it all, clipboard in hand, is Wilson, the house-keeper, an opaque woman in her middle y Barnes, who is carrying a large flat, crested case approa She does not look up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Just leave everything in one pile, make sure it’s properly labelled and it'll be taken up.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: These are the guns. Where’s the gun room? His voice could scarcely be more disdainful. She nods at corridor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: At the end on the left. You’1l find the keeper, Mr Strutt, in there. He’ll show you what to do.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: I know what to do. He goes as Mary arrives timidly, sheltering behind a lade Merriman .

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMAN
dialogues.text: The Countess of Trentham. Merriman has carried in the three smart cases. He knows t ropes. Mrs Wilson nods and checks her list, handing a lab the man.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Leave them over there by the luggage lift and tie this to the top one. You’ll find the chauffeur, Mr Raikes, in the courtyard. He’1ll tell you where to put the car. You’1l sleep in the stable block with the grooms. He sets about the task, leaving Mary feeling more alone t ever.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her ladyship is in the Blue Damask Room. You'll be sharing with the Head Parlourmaid. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She'll show you where everything is. Elsie, this is Miss Trentham. A young, uniformed maid, Elsie, turns at the sound of her and comes near

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, m’m, but.. my name’s Maceachran..

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Not here it's not. Mrs Wilson has moved away as Elsie takes Mary's case.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about the jewels? She indicates the dressing case still in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: This way. George is in charge of the safe. He’s the First Footman. And you want to watch where he puts his hands... They turn another corner in the maze of service corridors xun beneath the house. At the door of the Butler's Silver Pantry, stands a supercilious figure in livery. Next to h just inside the room, is a large wall safe. The iron door open revealing a felt-lined closet, filled with laden she George, the first footman, is receiving a case from anoth (Renee). Mary takes a key on a chain around her neck unde dress and opens the case, removing the jewel box which sh about to hand over

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you got the ones for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh... Mary unlocks the box. Inside are gleaming trays, each one complete parure of gems. She takes out a set of sapphires puts them in the pocket of her coat.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Always take a separate box with the first night’s jewels. Saves bother. Mary nods, re~locking the box and handing it over to Geor gives her a wink as he takes it. As they walk away, re-cr the back hall, they almost collide with a tall stranger c a suitcase. Mrs Wilson arrives.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Elsie, this is Lord Stockbridge’s valet. Show him the footmen's staircase, will you? And he’1l need the ironing room. She starts to leave. The new arrival turns to the two mai

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The name’s Robert, Robert Parks. This seems to halt the retreating Mrs Wilson. Robert look her enquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: I meant to say you'll be sharing with Mr Weissman's man. You could have gone up together but I don't know where he's got to. Other business claims her. Elsie sighs. They might as wel on with it.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Has his lordship’s luggage gone up?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Supposedly. He's in the Tapestry Room wherever that is.. Oh well, here, we go again. But Mary cannot return his casual pleasantry. Instead she whispers.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That‘s just it. I’ve never done a house-party before. Not properly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You'll be all right. Elsie, above them on the back stair, has overheard.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: How d’you manage to be taken on as a countess’s lady’s maid if you didn’t ‘ave no experience?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She wants to train me. She said she didn’t care about experience.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: She didn’t want to pay for it, you mean. INT. KITCHEN. DAY. A handsome face displays the brilliant smile of Henry Den Morris Weissman's valet. At the long table, the cook, Mrs is working on a tray of quail. The senior kitchen maid, B slices carrots and the junior, Ellen, slowly turns an ice churn. They ogle the visitor who speaks in a Scottish acc

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Get on with your work. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I just — But before he can say more, Mrs Wilson spies him from the corridor and enters.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Ah, Mr Weissman, there you are.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: I'm dealing with this. What is it, Mr Weissman? The dislike between the two women is almost tangible.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well, to start with my name is Denton. Henry Denton.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: You are here as valet to Mr Weissman. That means you will be known, below stairs, as Mr Weissman for the duration of your stay. You'll find we keep to the old customs, It avoids confusion. He would answer back but decides against it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's about Mr Weissman’s diet ~

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON AND MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He's a vegetarian.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: A vegetarian. He doesn’t eat meat. He eats fish but not meat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Well, I never.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry if it’s inconvenient.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not very convenient, I must say. Doesn’t eat meat? He’s come for a shooting party and he doesn’t eat meat?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mr Weissman doesn’t intend to shoot. I think he just wants to walk out with them. Get a bit of air.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Get a bit of air?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Thank you. We’1ll make the necessary adjustments. Now, if you'd like to get one of the servants to take you upstairs... Mr Weissman is in the Mulgrave Room and you’1ll be sharing with Lord Stockbridge’s valet. Henry nods his thanks and walks out of the room watched b Croft.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: He's very full of himself, I must say. Doesn’t eat meat!

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Come along, Mrs Croft. We don’t want to be thought unsophisticated, do we? Mr Weissman is an American. They do things differently there. She goes, leaving Mrs Croft seething. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: I’ll give her ‘unsophisticated’! Her assistants giggle but their response does not please cook.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you gawping at? Those are no good. I said ‘julienne.’ And Ellen that is ice-cream you are churning not concrete. Calm down. INT. ELSIE’S ATTIC ROOM. DAY. This is a simple, plainly furnished room with two beds. M hangs up her coat then opens the valise on the bed. She unbuttons her wet travelling dress and takes a black froc the case then a cap and a frilly, black apron. Elsie watc her.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I thought ladies’ maids never wore aprons.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Her ladyship used to have a French maid who wore a black one like this. She thinks it’s got a bit of style.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I bet she does. And I'll bet she took it out of your wages, too.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She likes to have everything just so. Elsie rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Don’t they all? Behind Elsie’s bed are various pictures of movie stars, postcards or cut from magazines. Mary goes over to the collection to admire it. She points.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That‘s him! This is surprising as the picture is principally of Garbo man behind her, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Who'd you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ivor Novello. He passed us on the road today, on his way here, and he spoke to me. Well... he spoke to her ladyship but I answered.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I only cut it out for Garbo. I prefer the American stars. I think they've got more oomph.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Go on. Is he really Sir William's cousin? Imagine having a film star in the family. Lady Sylvia must be thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I don't think.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't she be?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Because she's a snobbish cow. Because she looks down on anyone who got to the top with brains and hard work. dust like she looks down on her husband. Except when it's time to foot the bills. Then she’s got her hand out all right.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What was her family, then?

dialogues.speaker: ELSTE
dialogues.text: What you’d expect. Toffee-nosed and useless. Her father was the Earl of Carton which sounds good except he didn‘t have a pot to piss in.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What's she like to work for?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Horrible but he.. he’s O.K., Come on. We’d better get cracking.  10 12 INT. KITCHEN CORRIDOR. DAY. Probert, Sir William's valet, is carrying a boiled-front shirt past Mrs Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Can’t think why I’m so behind today. The gong hasn’t gone, has it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Oh no, you've plenty of time yet.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: ‘Cos you know what a fuss he’s in when he’s playing Mine Host...I think I'11 go and get him a paper if there's time... This last is to himself as he hurries on. Mrs Wilson noti something in the corridor that displeases her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: George? What are you up to? Hasn't Mr Jennings given you anything to do?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I‘m just going to help him with the tea. Then I'm to finish the table with Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Well get on with it then. With a movement suspiciously like the discarding of a cig he nods, starting up the service stair that leads to the house. INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. DAY. Emerging from the green baize door, George crosses a magn staircase hall. As he goes, he hears a whispered, angry e although he cannot detect the source.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (VO)
dialogues.text: What do you mean “no”? You promised!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN, (VO)
dialogues.text: I never promised! I said I’d do my best... Anyway, I’m going to ask him tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (VO)
dialogues.text: You'd bloody well better! What — This is provoked by George stepping from the rug to the p floor. The speaker, The Hon. Freddie Nesbitt, emerges. Hi anxiety dissolves at the sight of a footman.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: It's all right. It’s nobody. He is joined by a young woman, Isobel McCordile.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t sneak up on people like that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Miss Isobel. The camera stays with the servant as the others walk away voices fading.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: Do you really think you’1l have a chance to talk to him tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL, (VO)
dialogues.text: Oh, do stop going on about it.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE, (VO)
dialogues.text: That’s all very fine but why the hell do you think I’ve come here? George turns the handle of the saloon door, without knock and goes silentiy in. INT. SALOON/LIBRARY. DAY. Sitting at a table, surrounded by the evidence of a large are Constance Trentham, Morris Weissman, and Mabel Nesbit is holding court, enthralling Mabel with Hollywood gossip others sprawl around the room, balancing plates and cups magazines and cigarettes as they drawl and chatter, Jenni presides over the teapot. George, followed by Isobel, Fre and the Stockbridges, enters and takes his position by th as Lt. Commander Anthony and Lady Lavinia Meredith approa tea table, He is ex-navy, she is Sylvia's sister, Their t urgent and could not be overheard - except possibly by th butler.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: What do you mean “leave it?” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVINTA
dialogues.text: I just meant let it come up naturally. Don't steer the conversation. It makes you sound so desperate.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Well, I am fucking desperate. They cross the room to sit down, passing the tea-table. Constance.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: What's Greta Garbo really like? Did you get to know her?

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: I did. As a matter of fact, she's coming to stay with me next month. Mabel gasps. Her shop-girl awe reassures Ivor but it irri

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Tell me, how much longer do you think you'll go on making films?

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: That depends how much longer the public wants to see me in them.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I expect it's hard to know when it's time to throw in the towel...What a pity about that last one of yours. What was it? *The Dodger"?

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: "The Lodger“

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: It must be so disappointing...When something just flops like that. After all the hard work.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Yes, I suppose it is rather disappointing. Sylvia arrives at the table.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: You have some beautiful antiques, Lady Sylvia. Real museum quality. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il 15

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm interested: How much would a picture like that set you back?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I hope you've all got everything you need, She shares the moment with Constance before walking back the open library door where McCordle is sitting at a work covered with gun tools and a pistol feeding his terrier, Keeping him company is Louisa Stockbridge.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Who's the funny little American?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Morris Weissman? A friend of Ivor's. He makes films in Hollywood. Ivor asked if he could bring him and I didn't see why not. I thought he might be interested in shooting but...

dialogues.speaker: LOUITSA
dialogues.text: Never mind. He adds to the glamour of the gathering. I didn't expect anything half as exotic. During this, William goes to pour two whiskies. He splash little soda into them. Nearby a door set into the books o and Probert appears. He is surprised to find the room occ

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, Sir. I just thought I'd take the Times up with me. In case you want to read it when you dress.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Good thinking, Probert. As the valet looks for the paper, William hands the drink Louisa but she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Not for me. Far too early. And you know I never drink whisky.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Come on. Drink up. It's good for you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 il CONTINUED: (3)

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Really, Bill. You're such a bad influence. Don't blame me if I pass out at dinner. But she takes the drink and sips it as the valet takes th and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don't know how impressed your husband is with our Showbiz folk. He looks as if he's being forced to share a railway sleeper with a garage mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Tim afraid he only feels safe with his own kind.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Poor old Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Tf you think he's dull you should've met his father. He made Raymond look like Buster Keaton. 12 INT. KITCHEN CORRIDOR. EVE. Mary carries three evening frocks while Elsie carries one holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Mrs Nesbitt. She’s only got this one with her. Says her husband rushed her when she was packing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you always look after visitors if they don’t have a maid?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Sometimes Dorothy helps. Though why Mrs Wilson makes the Still Room Maid do it beats me...I think it's just to annoy Mrs Croft.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Which one does Dorothy answer to? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Both. And she's worked off her feet. But then I do Miss Isobel as well...Here we are. She opens a door and goes in. INT. IRONING AND SEWING ROOM. EVE. In the centre are several ironing boards. Barnes, Robert, and Renee are in there working. Robert brushes glaze on a evening waistcoat as he irons it.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: You found it, then? She smiles at Robert. Then points to a cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one's yours.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: E think here I’m called Trentham..

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. I meant your real name?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mary. Mary Maceachran.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Blimey. What does her ladyship call you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, it should be Maceachran. That’s what my mother says. Now I'ma lady’s maid. But she can’t pronounce it so she calls me Mary.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t blame her. Elsie irons with contempt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELSTE
dialogues.text: Machine-made lace.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Hark at her

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I hate cheap clothes. Twice the work and they never look any good.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: What d’you expect from a woman without her own maid?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Lady Lavinia always says a woman who travels with no maid has lost her self- respect. She calls it “giving in.’

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I don’t have a maid and T haven’t “given in.”

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That's different.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Yes, why is it different, Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Miss Morse to you. INT. KITCHEN CORRIDOR. EVE. Henry is carrying some clothes and a pair of stout shoes. goes, he opens every door and looks inside.. He marvels a complexities of the still room, then at the larders and s He jumps at the sound of a voice. It is Arthur, the Secon Footman.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I er.. I was looking for the brushing room. I thought I'd give Mr Weissman’s tweeds a going-over for tomorrow. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I'll show you.. Here y’are. He opens a door and Henry goes in. INT. BRUSHING ROOM. EVE. There is a covered table with every type of brush on it. Sylvia‘s maid, the shoes and lays out the tweeds. is working on the hacking jacket. Henry puts down

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: The boot room’s next door...Do you really live in Hollywood?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: But how did you get there? I mean, where did you start from?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Where do you think? Scotland. This answer is not quite satisfying to Arthur. He looks a Lewis. Then he presses on.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Were you always in service? Or did you ever think of trying to get into films? I wanted to be an actor once...when I was little...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Was that a bell?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: It’s not the dressing gong, is it?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Can't be time for them to change yet, surely. He goes off to investigate as Henry tries different brush suit the tweed. INT. RED SALOON. EVE. Tea is nearly finished. Jennings hands an empty tray to G (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Its nearly time for the gong. If they don't want any more, take their cups and plates. If they do, don't give them much. George walks towards the sofa on the left of the fire-pla

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Sylvia, I mean it. There mustn't be any nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about. Sylvia, without her hacking jacket but still in jodphurs, to her other brother-in-law, Raymond Stockbridge. With Ge camera, we hear them before we see them. Raymond sits rea magazine but it is clear that something has set him on ed

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you done a lot of shooting this year?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Quite a lot

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you finished, your ladyship? or would you like some more tea?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: All finished, thank you, George. So is Lord Stockbridge. He starts to clear as she looks across at the silent peer

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does Louisa always go out with you?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Usually.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: How good she is...It bores me stiff, I'm afraid. And William's such a rotten shot, he doesn't really like anyone standing with him. I try and duck out of it. Particularly if it's Scotland. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I'm very fond of Scotland.. He speaks without looking up as George takes his tray and over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: But what a waste! If you‘re not shooting either, then they'll only be six! William? Isn‘t that a shame... She addresses William who stands in the library doorway w Louisa. Anthony makes a move to speak to him but William' deter him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter...I'm going up to change.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Well, I am surprised. Normally anything to do with shooting or those wretched guns is sacrosanct. What is your secret, I wonder? Ivor drifts over to Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Zam sorry about that. I should have made it clear. Stupid of me.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Nonsense. It's William's fault. He just has this idea that all Americans sleep with guns under their pillows.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: So they do. But they’re more for each other than for killing birds. She laughs as Raymond looks up from his reading.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Remind me, how are you related to William exactly?

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Qur mothers were first cousins.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Really? I don't know that I ever met William's mother. Didn't she do something rather original? George crosses back to the now clear tea-table.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: She was a teacher. So was mine.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Oh? Well, of course that's marvellous, isn't it? Back at the table, Constance is ingratiating herself with neighbour.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Sylvia's so clever. She always finds such wonderful servants. I don't know how she manages. I'm breaking in a new maid and I'm simply worn out with it. There's nothing more exhausting, is there?

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: I don't have a lady's maid. She gives the information flatly but Constance remains li Sylvia has given up on Raymond and come to look for a cig in a box on the tea-table.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I was just telling dear Mabel here about my new maid. Honestly, for all the help I have to give her, she should be paying me...

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She does look rather young. Constance drops her voice so that only Sylvia (and George hear.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Well of course what she is, my dear, is wonderfully cheap. She laughs softly with her niece. During all this, George removed the cloth, and folded the tea-table.  23 16 INT. IRONING AND SEWING ROOM. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I s'pose Old Mother Trentham'1ll have her begging bowl out while she's here.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: She won't be bothering your employer. That's for sure.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What d‘'you mean? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIB
dialogues.text: ‘Cos Lady Lavinia Meredith hasn’t a penny to bless herself with

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: And who's fault is that?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with the Commander. He's just been a bit unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: T'll say. I think he's pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Then why don't you hand in your notice?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Well, the other two sisters fell on their feet. ‘Course, it helps that they’re good-looking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Lady Sylvia's lovely.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Doe you think so?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: She might have done a bit better for herself, really.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. Lord Carton was determined to get Six William for either of the two eldest. I was told he could have had his pick. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is in She goes. 24

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why was Lord Carton so keen?

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Why d'you think? Who d'you suppose pays for him to swan around Biarritz for six months a year. Come to that, who keeps Ma Trentham in stockings and gin? Old Money Bags, that's who.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I think it's disgusting. The way they use him. Especially when they all look down on him ‘cos he’s made it himself. None of them have got the brains to make the price of a packet of tea.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Have you finished, Elsie? the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Nearly, Mrs Wilson. I’ve just got these cuffs to do.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: When you're ready make your way to the Servants' Hall. We dine after the guests are dressed and before we serve dinner. Barnes follows, saying,

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Here we go. Yes sir, no sir, three bags full, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What’s Lord Stockbridge like?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: He thinks he's God Almighty but they all do. INT. DINING-ROOM. EVE. A beautiful and complicated table-setting fills the scree six glasses of different shapes and sizes, and silver cut ranged sideways out from a place mat supporting a folded (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On the right, among the spoons and knives is a single for all the other forks are on the left. A hand enters the fr takes it up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (VO)
dialogues.text: Why does this fork go on the right? Henry is examining it. Arthur, wearing green baize gloves moving silver, takes it back, spits on it, rubs it lightl replaces it.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Because they eat their fish with two of them. One in each hand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why's that then?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Search me. George enters. He carries a tray holding some full, xed w decanters.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Just looking around. George unloads the tray onto the sideboard then takes a r out of a drawer and starts to measure the exact distance the place settings.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mr Jennings‘ll be up in a minute. If I were you, I‘d go and ‘look around’ somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Whatever you say. With a smile, he leaves. Arthur waits until the door shut

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: There's something funny about that bloke..

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: His accent for a start. Where do you - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 a7 CONTINUED: (2)

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Are you finished? What about Lord Rupert Standish and Mr Blond? He stands in the other door. Frowning, he moves an entire setting slightly to the left.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Her ladyship said not to lay for them. The stuff’s ready if they get here in time. We can stick two more places on in a jiffy.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: When they arrive, you'll be dressing Mr Blond, Arthur. George, you’11 have Lord Rupert. Tf they’re very late, they can change by themselves. You can tidy up when they're downstairs. Is Mr Nesbitt settled?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I‘ll go up and finish him off now.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: And Mr Novello?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Mr Weissman’s man will attend to him. Right. As soon as you’re done, join me in the drawing-room for the drinks. He goes. George folds up the ruler and puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Nothing.. only I thought I'd be doing Mr Novello, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And now you won’t see him in his under- drawers? Never mind. Better luck next time. Arthur attempts to conceal his furious blushing. 18 INT. NOVELLO BEDROOM. EVE. Henry is tidying things while Ivor stands in white tie an before a pier glass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TVOR
dialogues.text: So, how’s it going? Are you enjoying yourself?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Very much. Are you, sir? INT. TRENTHAM BEDROOM. EVE. Constance, wearing the blue dress we saw Mary ironing and sapphires, is sitting in front of her looking glass. Mary arranges a small tiara in her mistress’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Rather a mixed bag. That Mr Weissman’s very odd. Apparently he's in films. He directs something called “The Charlie Chan Mysteries.” Or does he produce them? I never know the difference.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really? I enjoy those, milady. Constance lights a cigarette. She isn’t interested in Mar movie-going.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I suppose it’s fun to have a film star staying but there’s always so little to talk about after the first flush of recognition. And why has Freddie Nesbitt brought that awful, common wife of his? Isobel only asked him because a gun dropped out and that’s no excuse to inflict her on us all. And I'm told he’s been sacked from his bank now, Thank heaven he’s a younger son... So, what's the gossip in the servants’ hall?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nothing, really, milady. But Constance knows better than that as she puffs away.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Out with it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well... is it true that Sir William could have married Lady Stockbridge? If he'd wanted to? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ig

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Is that what they’re saying?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Only that Lord Carton was after Sir William for one of them and he didn't care which...

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: What would you say if I told you they cut cards for him?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What? They didn’t, did they? For a moment Constance relishes the shock on her maid’s f

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: O£ course not. Now, tomorrow morning I'll breakfast in bed and get straight up into the tweeds. What shirt have you brought?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The pink with the green check.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Oh no, dear. Quite wrong. Always something very plain for country sports. The one IT had on today will do.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But it’s soiled.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Well? You can wash it, can’t you. God, I hate shooting. Why does one have to do these things?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Couldn’t you stay indoors? Lady Sylvia wouldn’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Maybe not but he would. He’s terribly touchy. Worse since they made him a baronet. Now he thinks he’s the last Plantagenet and takes offence accordingly. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns a searching eye on her image in the glass, smea rouge into her cheek. INT. MCCORDLE DRESSING ROOM. EVE. Probert is putting the finishing touches to Six William's evening dress. The new baronet looks at the reflection of himself. His dog also checks out the final effect.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: And you really don’t think a handkerchief?

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: No, sir MeCordle reluctantly accepts his valet’s judgement. Probe the camera) crosses the door at the moment it opens and S appears, her hard beauty accentuated by the superb cut of clothes. When she speaks, it is difficult to mask her indifference.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I'm going down. Lewis said you wanted me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (VO)
dialogues.text: Who’s next to me at dinner?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You know who. Aunt Constance and Lavinia.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Why do I have to have the old trout the whole bloody time? Why can't I have Louisa?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Do you really want me to explain the Table of Precedence now? Or can it wait? Her voice is dripping with sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (VO)
dialogues.text: Who gives a shit about precedence? Probert walks over to put something into a tall-boy near in time for us to see her shrug, speaking wearily as she to a tiresome child. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You rage when people look down on you and then you insist on behaving like a vulgar ignoramus. Her contemptuous words have their effect. This is how she controls him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (VO)
dialogues.text: Has Constance asked you for any money yet? The camera has followed Probert as he continues to tidy t dressing-room. Now he takes a crested, ivory clothes brus a tall-boy and returns to Sir William.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Raymond says she’s been complaining that her allowance isn’t big enough. I’ve a good mind to stop it altogether.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I thought it was settled for her lifetime,

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Says who? His manner is bullying and unpleasant but Sylvia is uninterested.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Will that be all, sir? Probert restrains a smile as he carries the clothes brush to the dressing-table.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (VO)
dialogues.text: I wish Anthony wasn’t here. Try and make sure he doesn’t get me on my own, can you?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (VO)
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (VO)
dialogues.text: I’m pulling out of his scheme.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~ Probert brings the camera back to them and he stands, wai speak.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Oh? Have you told him?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. And I’m not going to if I can help it. Louisa thought I should do it next week. Then he can sob in private. Spare Lavinia’s blushes

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Far be it from me to contradict Louisa.. Poor little Anthony. I thought he was looking unusually pathetic at tea...Get away from me. She shoves Pip off her foot as Probert bows.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Will there be anything else, sir?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: C No, thank you, Probert. 21 INT. GALLERY. EVE. As Probert emerges, Elsie is coming down the gallery look harrassed.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Bverything all right, girl?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Honestly, I don’t know how I'll manage. She’s forgotten her hairpins. She hasn’t packed the right shoes.. I’m making bricks without straw, Mr Probert. Really I am. Mary appears, carrying the dirty shirt.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t suppose you've got any hairpins to spare, have you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hang on a minute. ( She rummages in a chatelaine and finds a few. Muttering Elsie hurries away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: On your way down? I'll take you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I thought I'd just nip up to my room for a minute...only...

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Which way is my room? INT. GALLERY. EVE. George is emerging from the Nesbitts’ bedroom as Elsie ar

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Is he done? He nods, raising his eyebrows, and goes. She reaches for door handle when there is a movement at the end of the ga William and his dog are both looking at her. With a secre smile, Elsie returns his gaze before she opens the door. INT. NESBITT BEDROOM. EVE. Mabel is at the dressing table and, for a moment, it seem Freddie has his wife’s wrist in his fist. He swings round if he did have hold of her, he releases it

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I’ve got some pins, madam, From Lady Trentham’s maid.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: We should be downstairs already.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: You go on. T‘ll be as quick as I can.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Try and make her look respectable. He says this to the maid and goes without a comment from woman. They stare at each other through the glass. Mabel her pasty face and lank hair looks terrible.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: Well, there’s no harm in trying.  24 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennings carries a salver with two martini glasses to Ivo is playing the grand piano. Is it ‘I Can Give You The Starlight”? He and Weissman take the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Just Jennings, sir

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Then thank you, Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I'll clear the piano for you, sir. He lifts the photographs and albums that litter the close of the grand as Sylvia approaches. Ivor stands but she ma play. Behind her, the others drift in.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Jennings, can I have a martini when you've done that? Oh, don’t get up. Go on. Please. What is it? I don’t believe I know it.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR,
dialogues.text: Nothing.. an idea I’ve been fiddling with.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: By the way, Jennings. I’ve a telephone call booked. For California. If you could let me know as soon as they get through.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I can't imagine how one could ever invent a tune.. How do you start?

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: It's rather hard to say exactly.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well I think it’s too clever for any words . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She strolls back to join the others. Weissman watches her Jennings finally lifts the lid of the piano, filling the with music. He starts back to the drinks table.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: How do you manage these people?

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: You forget. I make my living impersonating them. What does he want? Across the room, Henry has come in. He lingers by the doo Jennings approaches

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You know.. I really enjoy the way you do things, Mr Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. Weissman has left the piano and crossed the room.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: What is it, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just wanted to be sure you have everything you need. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: WETSSMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you Henry goes, leaving Jennings completely bewildered. Weiss acknowledges him.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s so good to find a servant these days who takes an interest. 25 INT. SERVANTS’ HALL. EVE. A table is laid for dinner with a nervous boy ready to se All the indoor servants except the kitchen staff are here including two housemaids, May and Janet. Merriman nods at Jennings enters with George and Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Everything satisfactory, Mr Jennings? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, Dorothy. They have their drinks. We can take our leisure for half an hour, I think. At the head of the table, he looks at Renee who stands on right. His brow darkens.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I did tell her, Mr Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: tT believe this is my place, Mr Jennings -

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Qh? Since when did a baroness outrank a countess? Or is that some foreign custom you've picked up on your travels? Renee purses her lips but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Trentham? Would you like to come and take the seat of honour? But Mary does not recognise her ‘name’. He repeats it and nudges her

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: t'm all right here, Mr Jennings, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Go on. Don't keep him waiting. Jennings stands. Mary, blushing, moves to his right hand displacing Renee who moves to Jennings’s left but even th not satisfy him,

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Miss Meredith, you may come to my left if you please. As Renee stalks down the table, Mary turns queryingly to He whispers. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Her mistress married a baron so she lost her rank as an earl’s daughter. Renee always tries to catch Mr Jennings out but no one can.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Naturally I’m nothing when there’s visitors in the house. Never mind. I’m used to it. No one pays her any attention as the housekeeper, Mrs Wil makes her own stately entrance and takes her place at the end between Robert and Probert.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr Jennings. Jennings nods, says Grace and they sit. The boy holds a p for Mrs Wilson and then the butler. Unlike upstairs, they vegetable dishes across the table.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Right. Start when you get it. No time for loitering.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Can I ask a question?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Certainly, Mr Weissman. How can we help?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I just wondered. How many people here had parents in service? And was that why they chose to go into it?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: That‘s an interesting point and one I can’t answer. All those of you whose parents were in service raise your hand. Most hands go up. We hear “not both of them” or “just for before they married,” “I s'pose they expected me to,” and Only Dorothy, Barnes and Robert are left.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not you, Dorothy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tC 25

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: My dad was a farmer, Mr Jennings. A tenant of Lord Carton’s.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Mx Meredith?

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Factory hands. Both of them. And if you ask me, they were better off.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What about you, Mr Stockbridge? Robert looks up. Something in this attracts Mrs Wilson's attention He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? Don’t you know?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yes I know. I know what both of them did as a matter of fact. But it didn’t have no effect on me. On my choice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Because I grew up in an orphanage. This wrong foots the company. Jennings quickly pulls a ve matters.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Weissman. For giving us something to think about... I must compliment Bertha on this stew. And Mrs Croft on the choice of the beef, of course. It’s delicious. Mary now has George on her other side. She whispers to hi

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where is Mrs Croft?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Always eats with her own staff. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Does she take her pudding to Mrs Wilson's room? Our cook does that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Not likely. She wouldn’t set foot in there if her life depended on it. They hate each other.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Something amusing, Miss Trentham? Can we share it? Mary is saved by the arrival of Lady Sylvia McCordle. In couture clothes and jewels, fairy kingdom. The company jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: IT am so sorry to disturb you all but a major crisis has arisen. I’ve just learned that Mr Weissman doesn’t eat meat. Is it a Jewish thing? I always thought that was pork and prawns...But the point is: What are we to do? I can’t tell Mrs Croft. I simply don’t dare.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Everything’s under control, your ladyship. Mr Weissman’s valet informed me as soon as they arrived. We’ve prepared a special version of the soup, he can eat the hors d’oevres and the fish and we'll do Welsh Rabbit for the game course. I’m not sure about the entree but we'll think of something. Sylvia's response is not as warm as it might be.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs Wilson. Of course you're ten steps ahead. Which one of you is Mr Weissman’s valet?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Iam, your ladyship. she is an enchanted creature from 4 Sylvia turns to deliver some patronising bon mot but she absolutely arrested by the man’s beauty. For a moment, sh simply stares.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Are you, indeed? Heavens... well... thank you for being so efficient. Please don't let me interrupt you further. She hurries away and they sit, dazed. George looks across Henry with a wink.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're all set, then. A few junior servants giggle which does not amuse Mr Jenn one bit.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Yes, George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nothing, Mr Jennings. They transfer their attention to their plates. EXT. KITCHEN COURT. NIGHT. Mary, carrying a cup of tea, is walking across the courty towards the garages for the visitors' cars. We can see Me there working on Constance's car. There is a sound from t shadows. Bertha is sitting by herself, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You gave me a turn. I didn't see you there. Aren't you cold?

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: It feels good to be cold after a day in that kitchen. Mary walks on until Merriman comes towards her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I thought you could do with this.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMAN
dialogues.text: That's kind, love. How are you getting on? Before Mary can answer, they are interrupted by the arriv an open roadster which sweeps in, all headlights and brig colour. It pulls to a halt and two young men, Lord Rupert Standish and Jeremy Blond, hop out.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Can we get in this way?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you do better round the front, six?

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Exactly what I said.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: The thing is we've got bags and guns and everything and neither of us has a man to carry them. I thought it made more sense to bring them to the back door. If I give you the keys perhaps someone can sort it out.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Of course. As she stands back to allow the men into the house, somet makes Jeremy turn. Bertha is watching them, smoking as sh against the outside wall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy and Janet tend a serving table, stacking plates a setting out clean ones from the heating cupboard. George with a dish of partridges, helping himself to a taste as into the dining-room. Elsie arrives and starts to follow

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You can’t go in there when you're not serving. What would Mr Jennings say?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Keep your hair on. It so happens I've got a message for your precious Mr Jennings. INT. DINING-ROOM, NIGHT. The party is at table. Because they are twelve, William s one end and Raymond (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: at the other, George holds the dish for Constance on Will right. Arthur waits with a tray of game crisps, breadcrum bread sauce and gravy

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: t was wondering if I could have a word with you. Alone. After dinner.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don’t think I should leave my guests, do you.. He leans down to feed Pip who sits beneath his chair.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: You'll make that dog sick. Weissman is talking to Louisa.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Of course I'm going out with them. Ivor's promised to look after me.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Ivor's going with you?

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Certainly. He says he's looking forward to a good walk.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Is he? Doesn't sound very like Ivor He normally stays in bed and comes out with the ladies for luncheon.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Well, he wants to show me how it all works. Before she can respond to this, a dish is brought by Arth Weissman’s left side.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Welsh Rabbit? Is that a vegetarian game course? Freddie is on Sylvia's left.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: It was just a misunderstanding. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Oh? Aunt Constance seemed to think it was more serious than that.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Only because she got her version from my father. On her right, Raymond eats in silence. There is a crack o thunder as she turns to him

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Ivor and Mabel are talking in the wrong direction so you’d better join us. It never seems to work when I’m mot at the end.. What a filthy night it's turning into. I’m afraid you'll all be drenched tomorrow but of course you'll say it doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It doesn’t. Beyond him, Isobel is listening to Anthony on her other s

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: What do you mean he’s losing interest in that sort of thing?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Not just that. The whole Empire. He thinks the steam’s gone out of it. Anxiously Anthony talks down the table, making the conver general.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: That’s not true is it, William? That you think the Empire’s finished?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Surely everyone feels the war changed things. Don’t they?

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: I don’t care what’s changed or not changed as long as our sons are spared what you all went through.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Not all. You never fought, did you, William? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I did my bit

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Of course you did

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, you made a lot of money but it’s not quite the same as charging into the camnon’s mouth, is it? Thank God for Raymond. At least the family had one representative in the front line Mabel turns to Ivor on her right, speaking sotto voce.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: What about Commander Meredith? He must have done something right.

dialogues.speaker: TVOR
dialogues.text: Not much. After ten years in the navy you're made Lieutenant Commander if you're not dead or in prison. No, Stockbridge was the here. Once he captured an entire battalion single- handed. He wal ked into the middle of them by accident and instead of panicking he told them he was the advance guard whereupon they all flung down their rifles on the spot. Trouble was there were three thousand of them and only one of him.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: But how splendid!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It was splendid. How many times were you mentioned in despatches, Raymond?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I forget. Throughout this, George and Arthur move round the table. Jennings stands surveying his troops. He moves forward fr to time to replenish an empty (red) wine glass. He is at table when he sees Elsie. Crossing over to her, he is alm fierce.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: What do you think you’re doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Mrs Wilson asked me to tell you that the others have come. This does ameliorate her fault. He goes to Sylvia's right speaking in a low voice.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Lord Rupert Standish and Mr Blond have arrived, milady.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: No, they're too late. Give them a tray in the billiard room. They can join us later.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Very good, milady. Isobel has heard. She leans over eagerly, her plain face with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Is Rupert here? Shall I go and say hello? e@

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.. Thank you, Jennings. As Jennings walks away, we can just hear one final interc

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: But I’m not a country girl at all.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: No. I grew up in Leicester. My father had a glove factory. One thing I do know is how a glove should fit.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Really, darling! You’re boring poor Mr Novello to death! Off camera, Ivor protests “Not at all” as Jennings reache door.  31 45

dialogues.speaker: INT. BILLIARD-ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Arthur is carrying a tray and he moves discreetly as the young men play billiards in a pool of light from the over fitting. They pay the footman no attention.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Face it. You're a younger son. With the tastes of a marquess and the income of a vicar. Here's the solution. She likes you. Her mother likes you. She’s not exactly a show- stopper but you can’t have everything.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Why’s it so important to you?

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Because if you marry badly, who's going to give me decent shooting in my old age?

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: The father’s not keen on the idea.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: He’ll come round. ‘Have you met my daughter, Lady Rupert Standish?’

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Maybe... He thinks I’m after her money.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Of course he does but you can’t let that put you off... “Faint heart never won fair lady.” Or, in this case, rich lady.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: He’s more of an obstacle than you think.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Then you must overcome it, mustn’t you? During this, Arthur quietly unloads plates from a tray on bridge table laid with a cloth, silver and glass. He stri match to light the candles in its centre. The noise and f flame alert the young men to his presence and they straig up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Her ladyship asks if you would join her in the drawing-room after you've finished.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Tf you'd ring when you're ready for your next course... He indicates a bell pull in the dado.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: We will. Thank you. Arthur goes. As he leaves Rupert speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Do you think he heard? INT. DINING-ROOM. NIGHT. The men are standing as the women leave. Jennings is the servant present.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Now, don’t be too long. William shuts the door and returns to his seat, inviting other men to join him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Move up, all of you.. Thank you, Jennings. They sit at his end of the table, irrespective of where t were before.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: I don't suppose there's any sign of my telephone call?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Not yet, I’m afraid, sir. The lines can be very busy... Jennings places a decanter of port in front of William, r its stopper.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Would you like me to ask Lord Rupert and Mr Blond to join you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Leave them be. They can entertain the ladies. Give Mr Novello a rest.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Is that Rupert Standish? Has he arrived?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Why? Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Certainly. We younger sons have to stick together. We’ve a lot in common. He imagines this will amuse William but, instead, his hos at him with disdain as he pours himself a glass and passe port to his left. Jennings brings the cigars.

dialogues.speaker: WILLTAM
dialogues.text: Yes. I expect you have. The butler leaves and we go with him. INT. SCULLERY. NIGHT. Among the bottles in this ancillary room, there are two w skull and cross bones sign of poison. Bertha checks the contents of a drawer. Mrs Croft is watching her.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: Arthur said he had to shout it down the table. Makes you feel sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: He's got nothing to be ashamed of. It’s not his fault if they put him in an orphanage.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: It's nobody's fault if it comes to that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: How do you know? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: No. It’s not here. And Mr Jennings is certain he hasn‘t got it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: So he says.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: But if it’s a silver carving knife, he must have it. It's just gone in the wrong drawer in the silver pantry. It wouldn't have been put in here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: That's what I told him. How old would you say he was? For a moment Bertha is puzzled then she remembers what th talking about.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: What do you think? Thirty one or two? Why?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: No reason.. I think T/11 turn in. We've got an early start. INT. WEISSMAN BEDROOM. NIGHT. Weissman, in his dressing-gown, reads a book by the fire sumptuous room.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Of course he won’t mind. I’1ll just say Iowant you with me.. By the way, I talked to Sheehan at the studio. The figures are worse than they thought. Not a single winner in the year. He sounded pretty desperate. He looks at the valet.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you come back later?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I should risk it, do you? There is something smug in the way he says this. He goes door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Oh Henry, don't forget those. Or they'll think you don’t care. Coolly, he nods at his dirty shirt, socks and underpants chair. They exchange a look. Silently, Henry picks them up and leaves. INT. SYLVIA‘S BEDROOM. NIGHT. Lewis helps Sylvia into a silk peignoir. The four-poster een turned down. An embroidered, gauze blanket-cover has replaced the counterpane.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Pleasant evening, milady?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Not really... I‘m worn out. She throws herself back among the pillows, Lewis strains the frock. She is old and the effort is great. But if the irony in their situation, neither is aware of it.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there any chocolate left in that pot? Lewis pauses to lift the lid of an exquisite little Sévre on the dressing table.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I’ll go down and make some more. INT. GALLERY. NIGHT. Lewis vanishes through the door to the back staircase as Denton enters the gallery. He is passing Sylvia’s door wh suddenly flies open.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Lewis! The suddenness of her apparition startles him for a momen returns Sylvia's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was looking for my maid.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: She’s just gone downstairs. Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She's fetching some chocolate for me but I’d rather have a glass of milk

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Would that be hot milk? Or cold?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I couldn't say, milady.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Hot, then... and with something to make it sweet...or I know I'll never shut my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why? Do you have trouble sleeping, milady?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, I've a feeling I will tonight. In fact, I know I'1li be wide awake at one and bored to sobs...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Then we must try to think of something to amuse you - As Barnes appears through a door further down, they break their contract made. Sylvia closes her door as Henry hear Anthony's voice.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (VO)
dialogues.text: I knew it. I knew he had something like this planned ~ Barnes rolls his eyes in Henry’s direction as they push t onto the back stair. INT. FOOTMEN’S ATTIC CORRIDOR. NIGHT. Mary is climbing the stairs. At the top, she stops. She i clearly lost. After a moment, she goes to one of the door knocks. There is an invitation to ‘come in.’  38 Si INT. ROBERT'S ATTIC ROOM. NIGHT. Henry is in his shirtsleeves. He looks up as Mary enters. stands, dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh... I’m ever so sorry.. I must have taken the wrong stairs.. But Henry is too quick for her. He pushes the door shut b her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don’t want to be seen up here or you'll be for it

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'd better go down...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There’s no rush, is there? Since you’re here now.. She is frozen, receiving his advances like a gazelle corn a tiger.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about a drink? I think we’ve both earned one. Out of his bag on the bed, he takes a bottle of whisky an sloshes some into two toothmugs on the wash stand. Holdin the glass with one hand, he slips the other round her wai pulls her to him and leans to kiss her when, she is sudde transformed into a vicious, spitting, fighting cat. As he away, stunned, they hear the noise of someone on the stai Quick as a flash, Mary pulls herself together. When the d opens and Robert enters, there is no trace left of the ru Naturally, he is amazed to see her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's this? Why are you in here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I came up the wrong staircase.1I was just waiting ‘til the coast was clear.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, you'd better get down again. Before anyone catches you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Holding open the door, he checks the corridor and nods. S goes. He shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tt think she's nice, that one.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Then you'd better go after her. You know what they say. He who hesitates is lost. This is not Robert's style at all but, if anything, he is by his companion's brashness. Henry scoops up the fallen smoothly pours two more drinks.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what do you make of the place? Robert shrugs. He sips the drink and sits, watching Henry his things.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, is this a well run house, would you say? Do you think Sir William would be good to work for? e

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. He does not elaborate. After a moment, Henry continues.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How long have you been doing this?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What? Valeting? About seven years. I was a footman before that.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: And working for Lord Stockbridge. Is that a promotion?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. I used to be with the Rarl of Flintshire

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Then why did you move?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: ‘Cos I felt like it. e@

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Henry nods. Beside Robert's bed there is a framed but old photograph of a woman.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Who‘s that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: My mum.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Where’s she live?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: She doesn’t. That's why they put me in the orphanage.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Of course. I’m sorry.. What happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What d’you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well... why did she die. I mean, was she young? Was it in childbirth?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're not very curious, are you? Yes, she was young. She worked in a factory, she had me and a little while later she died. End of story.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So why didn’t you say she was a factory worker at dinner?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: ‘Cos I didn’t fancy discussing my private life with a table of strangers. He picks up a book. Bven Henry is aware that he has overs the mark.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I spoke out of turn, mate. Didn’t mean to offend you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m not offended. And don’t call me ‘mate.’ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He returns his attention to his book. During this last ex Henry has put his jacket and tie back on again. He looks Robert. Clearly he is not going to get any more out of hi

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well. See you later. I've got a date with a glass of milk. He slips out of the room. INT. ELSIE’S ATTIC ROOM. NIGHT. Elsie pulls off her cap and shoes and slips out of her dr Mary is finishing unpacking. She is still a little shaken flops onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t worry about it. Goes with the territory... I’m bushed. I think Mrs Wilson forgets I do Miss Isobel on top of everything else. She is flicking through a Hollywood fan magazine. “Watch Step, Ann Dvorak!” or “Joan Crawford and Douglas Faixbank Course It’s For Keeps!” Until...

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ooh, look. There is a still of Ivor Novello with Benita Hume. Mary l over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: dust think of him sleeping downstairs...

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I shall have to watch you, my girl. I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Her ladyship says that Mr Weissman’s a Hollywood producer. He makes the Charlie Chan films.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I like those. I enjoy a bit of a fright in the cinema.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You could go with his valet. He'd give you a fright. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: They laugh together. Mary wrinkles her nose.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'd better keep your eye on him. I think he’s a funny one. He’s not from Scotland for a start. At least not from any part of it that I know. Elsie shrugs and goes back to her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's Mrs Nesbitt like?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: She’s 0.K. I feel a bit sorry for her, really.. ‘Course it never works.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What never works?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: When a man like that marries beneath him. He hasn’t got the brains to carry it off.

dialogues.speaker: C MARY
dialogues.text: ZI think it’s romantic. To marry for love. Mary picks up Elsie’s dress and cap. Elsie is more intere her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, it wasn’t love. Not him, He’s a nasty piece of work. The ‘honourable’ Freddie Nesbitt. That’s a laugh. It was her father’s money he was after but there was less than he thought. Now it’s spent and all he’s got to show is a wife he’s ashamed of. And he’s lost his job. He wants Miss Isobel to put in a word with Sir William.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Will she?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: She might.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ned Why should she?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Well, listen to you. Miss Nosie Parker... What‘s the matter? Mary has been distracted by the sight of a crumpled shirt chest.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I never washed that shirt. That's me in trouble...unless I do it now...

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Do you want me to come with you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, no. You stay there. I’1l be all xight. 40 INT. STILL ROOM. NIGHT. Mary pulls the plug from the sink and wrings out the shir leaves the room, crossing the corridor on her way to the room. 41 OMITTED e@

dialogues.speaker: 42A INT, IRONING AND SEWING ROOM. NIGHT.
dialogues.text: Mary enters the dark room, turning on the light. There is scuffling sound.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is someone there? There is silence. Then a smothered giggle.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Who is it? You're scaring me. Shyly, Bertha emerges from the shadows, smoothing down he skirts.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you up to? She speaks as she lowers the drying rack over the stove, arranges the shirt on it and winds it up again. Bertha sh BERTHA e@ Nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's not giving anything away. Mary nods and moves off b she is about to leave the room, she looks back into the d corner where a shaft of moonlight illuminates black shoes crumpled trousers and underpants revealing the hairy lowe calves of a man. The rest of him is in shadow. He is quit still. Without a word, she hurries out. INT. KITCHEN CORRIDOR, NIGHT. Mary is walking down the corridor when Mrs Wilson emerges

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Miss Trentham? Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: i was just washing a shirt of her ladyship's.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: I hope you found everything you needed. Lady Trentham’s tea will be laid out in the still-room any time after seven tomorrow. We‘ve remembered the cucumbers. Her breakfast tray may be collected at a quarter to nine.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She likes it at half past eight.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
