dialogues.text: I know but the shooting breakfast can delay the trays a little. It won’t be later. They move off at nine. Does she have to have marmalade? Dorothy made too little last January so we’ve run out of our own.. She wouldn't care for strawberry jam, I suppose?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not really..

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Very well. It isn’t a problem. There is a noise. Sir William McCordle is approaching dow corridor. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh... I was rather hoping for a word with Mrs Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: O£ course, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Mrs Wilson, I wonder if you could tell Jennings that I want the soup after the fourth drive tomorrow... Is this really what he came to say? As Mary goes, Mrs Wil closed the door. 44 INT. FOOTMEN'S ATTIC CORRIDOR. NIGHT. Henry backs out of the bedroom door, shuts it carefully, sets off down the stairs. 45 EXT. GOSFORD PARK. DAY. It is a grey morning. Men gather as two wagonettes are pu to the front. 46 INT. TRENTHAM BEDROOM. DAY. e@ A fire crackles merrily in the grate. Constance is sittin bed. She smooths the sheet before her, eagerly anticipati tray that Mary is carrying in from the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: They always send up a good breakfast here. I‘ll say that for Sylvia. She's not at all mean in that way... Mary places the pretty tray across her mistress. Constanc the lid of a china jam pot and wrinkles her nose.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bought marmalade! Dear me. I call that very feeble.. Oh well. I suppose one can’t have everything. Mary, I don’t think I will wear that shirt after all. The check’s warmer and that’s all I care about. She starts to eat. Mary, suppressing irritation, looks ou the window.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They're just getting ready to move off.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Ugh. Look. It’s already starting to rain.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You’1l enjoy the luncheon.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Nursery stew in a howling draft? I doubt it. EXT. GOSFORD PARK. DAY. Strutt is with the loaders. It is drizzling slightly.

dialogues.speaker: STRUTT
dialogues.text: We're only six guns now and, apart from Sir William, they’re shooting doubles or singles so we won't need you all. D’you want to toss for it?

dialogues.speaker: DERWENT
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: STRUTT
dialogues.text: The American gentleman. He’s a vegetarian. And vegetarians don’t shoot, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBIE
dialogues.text: Bloody he11... They all start to laugh, including Strutt, but then he qu them down.

dialogues.speaker: STRUTT
dialogues.text: That’/11 do. And remember, no comments on the skills of the gun you’re loading for unless you‘re asked. Understood? That goes for you too, Baker.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Honestly, Mr Strutt. I thought he had asked... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: STRUTT
dialogues.text: Well, he thought he hadn't. And straight faces. Even if they can’t hit a barn door. 48 INT. SERVANTS’ HALL. DAY. Henry, in his overcoat, is being interrogated by Barnes, George and Arthur. Probert is polishing a fob watch and a of the maids, including Mary, look on.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: What d’you mean you’re ‘going shooting'?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mr Weissman wants me to accompany him. Nothing wrong in that.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: But what for? You're not even loading. He hasn’t got a gun.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well... he might need something. @

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What could he need? George is imitating Henry's voice insultingly. Probert co Henry’s aid.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Of course the very idea of service is offensive to you, George, but there’s no need to take it out on the rest of us. Please forgive our ill manners, Mr Weissman Henry smiles a trifle nervously as he heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: I think he’s got something to hide, that one.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: We’ve all got something to hide, Mr Meredith. Robert catches Mary’s eye as he picks up a newspaper from table. @  61 eo 49 EXT. GOSFORD PARK. DAY. Henry, out of place in his coat, slips from a side door l around for Weissman.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: STRUTT
dialogues.text: Haven’t a clue. Right. Baker, you take Lord Stockbridge. You won't have to teach him much. Derwent and Crosbie, Sir William as usual. Tozer, Mr Nesbitt there... Once instructed, the men break away from the group and ap the gun they have been allotted to. William has three gun shared between his two loaders. Stockbridge, Standish and Meredith all have a pair. Nesbitt and Blond have one each William holds out a slotted pouch containing flat, ivory One by one, the guns choose a spill and read a number alt William keeps his finger fixed on one. At the end, he pul out before gathering the others € WILLIAM . I’m Four. Right. We’re turning on six. Evens go up two, odds down two. No ground game. Any white pheasants will cost you a fiver.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: I’ll come and cheer you on. But this suggestion does not seem to find favour. As Weis settles himself into the wagonette, Raymond, next to him, softly.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: He won’t let you. He can’t stand witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: But I keep hearing how he’s such an expert.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: He’s an expert gunsmith. It isn’t quite the same as being a good shot...

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: ( Why wouldn’t he let anyone have number four? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Why do you think? It’s the best peg.. That fellow’s trying to attract your attention. Weissman looks over to where the oddly-dressed Henry stan beckons him over.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: It's just my man.. It‘s all right for him to keep me company, isn’t it? Raymond looks at him. Clearly this is an amazing suggesti INT. ISOBEL‘S BEDROOM. DAY. Isobel gazes out at the garden.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Do you want to change now, miss? Or shall IT come back later?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: He won’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Who won’t do what, miss?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: My father... He won‘’t give Freddie a job. I spoke to him last night and he said he’d think about it but this morning, he says it isn’t up to him — when of course it is...

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL,
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Something to do with why Freddie was sacked but I can’t get a straight answer out of either of them.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Well, you’ve done your best. Mr Nesbitt can’t ask more than that.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Oh, but he can. Much more... He says he’s going to tell him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She has risen to her feet and is roaming the room like an animal. This is a facer.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Do you think he will?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.. He says Daddy’11 give him a job to keep him quiet. She hesitates. She turns back to Elsie, her awkward face with desperation.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Could you say something?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: To Mr Nesbitt?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: To Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Really, miss. Why ever would you think I could make any difference? Her tone is disingenuous but Isobel looks at her coolly.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Will you? EXT. AN OPEN DRIVE. DAY. The drive is about to begin. A horn blows. McCordle is re gun in hand. Behind him stand his loaders, Derwent and Cr each holding a gun. The first flush of birds fly over. Si William lifts his gun and fires both barrels, one after t other.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Damn! He swiftly changes guns with Derwent who reloads as Sir W fires again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Blast! He changes guns with Crosbie who starts to reload. More s from Sir William. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I pricked that one. From the expressions of the loaders as they share a look, clear they do not agree. The shooting is heavy now until suddenly a shot just misses them. All three duck.

dialogues.speaker: DERWENT
dialogues.text: Bugger me!

dialogues.speaker: CROSBIE
dialogues.text: You all right, six?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. I am not all right. To his and their astonishment, a tiny trickle of blood ma ear.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBIE
dialogues.text: Blimey.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Where the bloody hell did that come £rom? e@

dialogues.speaker: DERWENT
dialogues.text: Further down the line, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: At the end of the drive, find Strutt. See if he knows. If he does, he can tell the gun responsible to go back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBIE
dialogues.text: Here they come again, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right. With a sigh of recovery, he takes up his gun again and fi

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn it! Crosbie looks over to Derwent and rolls his eyes skyward. 52 INT. TRENTHAM BEDROOM. DAY. Mary comes in. Constance is at the dressing-table. Sylvia on the bed, Louisa and Lavinia are seated. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They are all dressed for a shooting lunch in rather heart tweeds than they travelled in. They wear walking shoes an already in country hats.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Did you find one?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh yes. She kneels down by her mistress and takes out a brown sho With Constance’s foot on her lap, Mary removes the broken and replaces it during the scene.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: There's no point in looking at me. If I open my mouth on the subject, it'll only make things worse.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: I’ve already tried. I don’t mind having another go but it won’t do any good. The door opens and Isobel appears. She is now in her twee which are not becoming. The others whisper conspiratorial ‘Come in!’ or ‘Shut the door!’

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Jennings says the cars are ready.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Goody. I’m starving. I do love a shooting luncheon. Mary looks up. Sylvia is examining her daughter dispassio

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Why? Don’t you like it? You bought it.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Did I? How extraordinary of me. Come on. We'd better get going. Where’s the wretched Mabel? Is she downstairs? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She goes, 66 (2)

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: And has anyone checked her outfit? She’s probably in black velvet with a feather in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: She’s in the morning-room looking perfectly normal. And don’t be such a snob, Aunt Constance.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Me? I haven‘t a snobbish bone in my body . indignant at the charge. Isobel at the rear, this moment with Mary. INT. ROBERT’S ATTIC ROOM. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't realise you were in - just my routine inspection.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry? So how are you settling in with Lerd Stockbridge? I know you haven't been with him for long. You know smoking isn't allowed up here. Stubs cigarette ~ sees photo. EXT. /INT.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope you have everything you require to make his Lordship comfortable. We haven't forgotten anything.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I can't believe you forget much Mrs Wilson. OPEN FIELD/TEMPLE. DAY. shares George is in the back of a farm truck with large baskets surrounding him. There are also crates of wine, of various sizes, covered with white cloths. jugs and bowls (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The vehicle approaches a temple with a terrace on which w see that the guns, Ivor, Weissman and the ladies have gat Below it, Jennings is running forward.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Where have you been? They’ve already broken for luncheon. Take the Bloody Mary. And hurry. George lifts two covered jugs from a bucket of ice on the of the wagon and starts toward the temple. He passes MecC and Strutt. The latter is shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: STRUTT
dialogues.text: Well, they didn’t, sir. It was a heavy drive, the loaders were busy and nobody saw. I’m sorry. George, carrying his jugs, takes the camera over to the b of a stone staircase where Raymond and Sylvia stand. As u we hear only what the footman hears.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: T'm warning you

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What? What exactly are you warning me of? She falls silent as she sees the footman. At the top of t stair, George enters the temple. Jennings hurries in behi and starts to unload the stew from the baskets. Henry Den watches as George arranges glasses on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Can I do anything to help, Mr Jennings? Jennings is threatened with the spectre of bad management a second, he nods.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Well, since you're here.. you might take the sherry round.. Henry lifts a tray with a decanter and glasses. As he and start for the terrace, they pass the Merediths who appear arguing out of sight of the other guests.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Just calm down.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You don't seem to understand how serious this is.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: We'll manage, we always have.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Oh yes. And how long do you think we'll go on managing if he sticks to it. I don't see why you can't get your sisters to help.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Darling, I've tried. Of course I've tried. But you know what they're like.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: I know they couldn't care less if we go under. Why should they? Their dressmakers will still be busy and their dinners served on time.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: What does that matter? Why can't you see that we've got what they'll never have. And they know it. Do you honestly think I'd change places with either of them?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Isn't it? Anyway, promise me you'll leave it for now. This is not the right moment.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: There is no sodding right moment! Anthony moves outside. McCordle is talking to Jeremy and Anthony waits for him as George and Henry start to hand r the drinks. We follow them and hear snatches of what is b said. All these exchanges overlap each other.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: That’s your problem.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: But I don’t see what more I can do.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In the background, Sylvia is winding a gramophone. She li needle and it starts to play “The Land Of Might Have Been few clap as Ivor bows to his hostess.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Very tactful.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I thought so. I borrowed it off Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Isn't this fun? There’s nothing like a day out with the guns, is there?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Nothing. Shall we go in? It's going to pelt in a minute. Ivor moves over to Weissman taking a telegram out of his

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: I nearly forgot. This came for you. About an hour ago. Henry joins them as Weissman reads it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Good or bad?

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Neither. Winfield Sheehan wants to talk to me. I’11 call him later. He explains to Ivor.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Head of Production at Fox. He's handling the next Charlie Chan. tsobel has left Freddie and joins Rupert, passing Jeremy Raymond on the way

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: You had a fantastic one in the third drive. It was a mile high.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: That’s generous but I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Would you like to come and see how we manage it at Stanton? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next month perhaps. I can give you four dates to choose from. This is to Isobel who smiles. Then she sees as Jeremy win Rupert. Behind, McCordle crosses. Anthony pounces.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: William! He tries what he imagines is a casual chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You weren’t serious last night, were you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’m afraid so. I was going to tell you next week but since you asked William is irritated. This is exactly what he wanted to a He looks about for help and seeing George, he holds up hi for some more.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: The thing is.. I don’t think you’ve grasped what this would do to the whole project. What it would do to me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Come on. It’s not as black as all that.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Yes, it bloody well is.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sorry to hear it, Anthony. But business is business. I‘m not a Charity Commissioner, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake, William, I’m begging you — Impulsively, he siezes the other man’s forearm forgetting the full glass of Bloody Mary. It shatters on the paving. Anthony is horrified. He takes out a handkerchief, offeri to McCordle.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, old man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Just leave it His anger is obvious but contained as George stoops to pi the pieces and Jennings comes into the doorway. He is jus time. The rain is starting again.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Luncheon is served. The company hurries in to the gorgeous table where the se wait for them.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I love a picnic, don’t you? INT. MAIDS’ ATTIC CORRIDOR. DAY. Elsie, in a dressing-gown and carrying a sponge bag, open door at the end of the corridor. We hear a squawk and a s INT. SERVANTS’ ATTIC BATHROOM. DAY. The room is small and spartan without decoration of any s Mary, embarrassed and covering herself, has been surprise the bath.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Shut the door for heaven’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: It's only Lewis. If any of the men were found up here they’d be sacked on the spot. Worse luck. She settles herself on the mean, cork-covered stool. Mary finishes her washing, uneasily concealed behind her arm a flannel. Elsie watches her, amused

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me you’re a convent girl. Or is it Presbyterian modesty? Is the water hot?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not very.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: No. And it won't be ‘til the guns come home. I'd better get into yours.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Her Ladyship says Sir William loves his shooting.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he does. Can't hit a barn door but he does love it. Sweet, really

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Last night - no, I shouldn't say.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Yes, you should. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Only that...when I went down to wash that shirt, I think he was in the ironing-room. With one of the kitchen maids.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: No. It wouldn't have been him. She is surprisingly definite.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think it was. Leastways, he came down the passage a moment later and I don't see how -

dialogues.speaker: BLSIE
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't him. Hurry up. She starts to undress.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SERVANTS ATTIC BATHROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Now Mary is putting on her dressing-gown and drying her h while Elsie ig in the bath. She is more comfortable to ba with a witness than Mary was. They have settled into a go

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You know when you said Sir William could have had his pick? Between Lady Sylvia and Lady Stockbridge?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: well, I asked her Ladyship about it and she said...they cut cards for him. She shares the wicked thought with Elsie.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I can't believe it either. I s'pose it was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be too sure. I heard... She breaks off with a sigh, catching herself out.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Why do we spend our time living through them...? Look at poor old Lewis. If her own mother had a heart attack, she'd think it was less important than one of Lady Sylvia's farts. He always says - She remembers herself and breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Who? Who says what?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Never mind. Doesn't matter...I dunno...all I want is to be at the centre of my own life. ‘Course if you say that in this house, Mr Jennings thinks you're planning to blow up the Romanovs . There is a bang on the door. From outside we hear an angu voice.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Are you ever coming cut?  57 74 INT. TRENTHAM BEDROOM. EVE. Mary is fastening Constance into another of the dresses t saw being hung up earlier with another of the sets of jew The mistress is in a jolly mood.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: You must know. You can’t fool me. If there’s one thing I don’t look for in amaid, it’s discretion. Except with my own secrets, of course.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know much, milady.. Apparently, he was counting on Sir William for an investment and had “guaranteed his interest” — whatever that means.. Anyway, Mr Barnes — the Commander’s valet — said he wanted to leave at once but Lady Lavinia’s persuaded him to stay until tomorrow. To make less of a thing of it. There is a brisk knock and Sylvia enters. She completely Mary .

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’m on my way down. This is just a quick warning. For God’s sake be careful not to rub him up, tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: EZ don’t know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You know exactly what I mean. He’s in a filthy mood. With everyone... He’s talking about stopping your allowance.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: But it’s for life! That was settled! He can’t do that!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Just you watch him. He’s absolutely spoiling for a fight and if you'll take my advice, you won’t give him one... I’ve got to go. She hurries out. This exchange has been in and out of vis we follow Mary putting things away. Constance catches her through the mirror. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Now that you can be discreet about...

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. EVE
dialogues.text: Jennings, with whisky, glasses etc., crosses the hall. We is on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: What am I going to do about it? I‘m going to call his Goddamn bluff. I‘l1l meet his fucking deadline. That’s what I’m going to do about it! We just see Sylvia and Louisa respond to his language as Jennings gets to the library. INT, LIBRARY. EVE. Jennings opens the door without knocking. He stops dead. men are seated round the fire. William, Novello and Henry William is surly as he pets his dog.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Is her ladyship down yet?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: They’re just assembling in the drawing- room now, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, it won’t kill them to wait five minutes. He starts to pour as Weissman comes in behind him, taking drink from the tray.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Wait for it: Sheehan wants a final seript by the fifteenth.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: That's crazy. You‘ve only just worked out the story.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That’s all, Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (VO)
dialogues.text: He knows that. He’s just wants an excuse to renegotiate. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (VO)
dialogues.text: He thinks he's losing the studio... There's talk about Zanuck coming in... But during this Jennings has left and we with him. INT. KITCHEN CORRIDOR. EVE. Jennings is walking toward his own room when Mrs Croft se

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr Jennings, has that knife turned up yet?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Not now. He goes into his room and shuts the door. Further down th corridor, Mrs Wilson is watching. Mrs Croft retrieves her dignity and retreats into the kitchen. INT. DINING-ROOM. EVE. Dinner is almost finished. In contrast to the night befor atmosphere is terrible. George, Arthur and Elsie are carr round the savouries. Jennings pours wine. William is sulk few of the guests are trying to keep things going.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Goodness, isn't it pretty, here? The house has such a lovely position.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: The best view’s from the old water tower. We might walk up there tomorrow. I suppose you really do have to get back to London?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we should. When you're ruined, there’s such a lot to do. This succeeds in further flattening the company as well a exasperating Lavinia and infuriating William. The servant exchange glances as they labour on round.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Would anyone care for a game of bridge after dinner?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Who else? What about you, Louisa?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: q don’t think so. I've rather gone off cards. I've never been very lucky with them. Almost inadvertently, she catches William’s eye. He holds glance, subdued.

dialogues.speaker: WILLTAM
dialogues.text: Nor me. For some reason, this both annoys Sylvia and spurs her in duty as a hostess.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Tell me again, Mr Weissman, what’s this film you’re working on?

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: “Charlie Chan in London.” It’s a detective mystery.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: Set in London.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Not really. Most of it takes place at a country house-party. Rather like this one... That’s where the murder happens.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: How horrid! And who turns out to have done it?

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: ~ couldn’t tell you that. It‘d spoil it for you.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: But none of us will ever see it. Her rudeness is quite unconscious. Rupert feels sorry for Weissman.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: And are you thinking of making it here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Oh no. We'll build it in the studio, I just wanted to experience a little country living while I was in England and Ivor was good enough to say he could fix it for me.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: It was William who could fix it.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Are you interested in films, sir?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Not likely.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Why shouldn’t I be? You don’t know what I’m interested in.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, I know you’re interested in money and in fiddling with those dreary guns but I agree. When it comes te anything else, I'm stumped.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: That’s not fair, is it, Bill? You always — With these words, she has broken the basic rule of domest service. She has released terrible reverberations by spea she did to William. Not only has she called him ‘Billi,’ engaged in the conversation of the family. The table is a Silent as the dead, forks are stilled in mid-air, glasses way to lips. Elsie realises that in one tiny second, in l than a second, she has terminated her employment in that After a moment of total immobility, William throws down h napkin and storms out. Raymond is the first to break the silence. With his voice normality returns.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Sylvia, did you ever manage to track down that magnolia you were after? Because, if not, I may have rather a good substitute.  tC 62 63 79 INT. MAIDS’ ATTIC CORRIDOR. EVE. Mary comes out of her room, heading for the stairs when E in tears, pushes past.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Elsie? What's the matter? But the girl only goes into the room and slams the door. INT. DINING-ROOM. EVE. Mary slips in. George and Arthur, with butler’s trays, ar clearing. George, in baize gloves, helps himself to the e the odd wine glass. Lingering in the room are Probert, Ba Sarah, Renee, Robert, Dorothy, Lewis and May.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: it’s true then?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You should have seen it.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: What's going to happen to her?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: She‘1l be lucky if they don’t boot her out before the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But she’s worked here so long..

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Shall I tell you what that means to them? Bugger all.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Please, Mx Meredith. There are ladies present... Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: In the library and he won’t come out again tonight At this point the door opens and Jennings appears. He loo around at the company.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: May I ask what is going on? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: We were just...

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: George, will you join me in the drawing-room, please? May, stay and help with the clearing. The rest of you can go back downstairs. I must say I’m surprised at you.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: But Mr Jennings — To her dismay, he simply turns and leaves. George winks a as he follows.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bet you're glad you came. INT. DRAWING-ROOM. EVE. Janet has brought in a tray. She goes into the dining roo George takes the tray to hand round the coffee. Constance the bridge table waiting. Rupert is talking softly to Iso Sylvia approaches Ivor by the chimneypiece.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Ivor, darling, is it too awful to ask you to play something? And brighten things up a bit? It would be such a treat

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Of course. He and Weissman walk towards the piano.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: I've booked a passage and I'11 live on the ‘phone ‘til I sail. But I have to get back to London tomorrow. I can go by train, if you’d rather stay.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: No, no. I'll take you.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: You're providing a lot of entertainment for nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Morris. I'm used to it. He starts to play "The Land of Might Have Been". Rupert a Isobel go to take their places at the card table. Jeremy whispers to Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Good work, old chap. You're doing awfully well.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: You don't understand. I - George holds the tray for Constance who looks up as she p herself a cup at Mabel lingering for a moment by the card behind Freddie.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: My maid was saying how sensible you are to travel light. After all, why should one wear a different frock every evening. We're not in a fashion parade. The players have drawn for dealer and Constance has won. Isobel cuts the cards for her, Mabel wanders over to the in her humiliation. INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. EVE. Robert and Mary are walking towards one of the two green doors.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: How could she let him touch her?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You sound as if you don’t like him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: All right then. Surprise me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Maybe I will. But she is distracted. From the drawing-room comes the so music. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Listen. INT. DRAWING~ROOM. EVE. Ivor is singing another song. The players are bidding. is already bored with the music.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: What a lovely, long repertoire. Rupert whispers to Isobel over their cards.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: I was wondering if we could have a word later.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Of course. If you like. Constance Nearby, Jeremy winks in approval, which Isobel notices. A Constance has won the bidding, Freddie is dummy. Having l his cards, he stands.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: I won't be a minute. He walks to the door. Mabel, by the piano, watches him go INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. EVE. Mrs Wilson appears with a tray of coffee things. She cros hall. INT. LIBRARY. EVE. William works at his gun table. The tools of his hobby su him. He has re-routed his rage and now he files a metal p with angry passion and finesse. The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: I’ve brought you some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: If I’d wanted coffee I'd have rung for it! With an impatient gesture he knocks the tray out of her h She starts to pick it up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never mind that! Just get me some whisky! Silently, she stands with the tray and goes to pour the d Her back is to him and she takes her time. He ignores her sets the drink before him and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM. EVE
dialogues.text: Ivor is still singing. The house-party has had enough. Ru dealing the next hand.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: You‘re spoiling us, Mr Novello. Quel embarras de richesses...Where on earth has Freddie got to?

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: I'll play if you like. Until he gets back. He sits between the lovers. At the other end of the room, Anthony silently steals from the room. Lavinia starts tow him,

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Anthony - But he has gone. She returns to her seat on the sofa. Mea Jennings, near the door, is in heaven. George tips the re of the milk jug into a cup. He then turns to the enraptur butler and whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Better get some more milk, Mr Jennings... I won’t be a moment. He holds the empty jug for Jennings to see. He goes to th dining-room door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING-ROOM. EVE
dialogues.text: As he comes in, Janet and May have paused in their cleari Arthur stands unashamedly by the connecting door. George bumps into him.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Why ever have you come out? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You can have enough of a good thing. I want a fag. He goes. INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. EVE. Renee, Barnes, Sarah and Probert and a reluctant Lewis cr of the green baize door. Sarah looks back down the stairs

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Where’s Mr Denton? The others 'sssh' her, further emphasising the illicitnes their presence.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: This isn't right, Mr Probert.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, go on. We're not the only ones. He nods towards Mary standing listening a little way off. smiles guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I couldn't resist. I was just saying to Mr Par - She looks round and to her surprise, he has gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. He's gone. INT. THE BASE OF THE KITCHEN STAIRS. EVE. Mrs Croft, the kitchen maids and Dorothy listen. Mrs Wils comes downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Dorothy. Get on with your work.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but Dorothy is under my jurisdiction as well, you know. And i say she can listen to a spot of music if she likes. Without another word, Mrs Wilson goes into her own room.  73 74 75 76 85 INT. MAIDS’ ATTIC CORRIDOR. EVE./NIGHT. Henry arrives at a door and knocks gently. Elsie opens it has been crying but she is calm now.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Yes? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I thought you might need cheering up...

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Did you? Well, you were wrong. She shuts the door, leaving him alone. INT. /EXT. BACK DOOR/COURTYARD. NIGHT. The door opens and a pair of male legs and feet, clad in trousers and shoes appear (it could be any of the men, ab below stairs). It is raining and, for a second, the feet hesitate. Their owner appears to spy some large, muddy wa over-shoes left by a gardener in the porch. The man slips feet, still in their black pumps, into them. There is a n He freezes. Mrs Croft appears through the crack of the op door. She pulls it to and we hear the bolt. After a momen legs approach. They strain but the door won’t budge. INT. DRAWING-ROOM. NIGHT. Constance, bored to sobs, looks around as she takes a liq from Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Where’s Anthony? You don’t suppose he’s gone to worry William again, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Even Anthony couldn’t be that stupid. Mabel looks over sharply at Constance who greets her with cheery smile. INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. NIGHT. The boots entex the front door, leaving a muddy trail. Th is quite audible.  77 78 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A secret door in the bookshelves opens gently as the boot slip in. Leaving a trail of mud, he moves softly across t floor until William’s feet come into view. The camera mov to reveal William in a fiercely concentrated position, ho some part of a gun quite still. He seems frozen. The empt is on its side on the table. The hand of the intruder lif sight. It is covered in a green baize glove, the type we seen in Scenes 15 and 61 and it holds the missing knife. semi-circular arc, the blade flashes down, over William’s shoulder and into his heart. Silently, William slumps for onto the table, his face crushed into the tools of his ho Below him, the wretched Pip whines. After a fraction of a second, the unknown assailant retreats. The concealed boo door closes behind him. INT. DRAWING-ROOM. NIGHT. Freddie returns. Jeremy makes to rise but Freddie stops h Mabel comes over.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: No, no. Finish the hand.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Never mind. Now Anthony Meredith slides back into the room. In answer Lavinia's enquiries, he just shakes his head reassuringly George returns with the jug. Jennings speaks sharply unde breath.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Well if that’s a ‘moment’ I’d like to know what happens when you take a real break. Now give her ladyship some more coffee. George takes the tray and approaches Sylvia. She holds ou cup.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: George, do you know what‘s become of Sir William?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I believe he’s still in the library, milady. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Louisa gets her refill. She is helping herself to milk an so George is still and we can see Sylvia raising her eyeb her sister as she drops her voice.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: I could try and fetch him if you like.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Would you, really? He much prefers you to me. INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR / RED SALOON. NIGHT. Mary, Probert and Lewis are still listening as Robert rej them. He carries two hot water bottles and hands one over Mary. It is in a cover bearing the coronetted ‘T.’

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Here. I did yours as well. Before the rush starts. Probert and Lewis acknowledge it is time to get to work. walk away, past the door of the red saloon where we see L In front of her, Pip noses his way out of the almost clos library door and looks around. Louisa picks him up.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Come here you horrid little thing. William, I - But the rest of her speech is swallowed in a scream. At o the music stops. The guests, followed by the different gr listening servants, cluster into the red saloon. Isobel c forward but Rupert shields her until a sob from Probert b them all to the door of the library. Mabel screams.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bleedin' hell... The body of Sir William McCordle is slumped over his work The eyes are open in the red face and the tongue is lolli It is clear that Sir William is very dead.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 81 82 88 EXT. GOSFORD PARK. NIGHT. A police car arrives. The driver, Constable Dexter, is jo Inspector Thompson. Vain and clottish, he feels he belong ‘upstairs’. The house party will not agree INT. SERVANTS' HALL. NIGHT. The servants are all seated round the table. Some of them including Elsie, are in dressing-gowns. The atmosphere is The news is shocking but not particularly sad. Apart from and the upper servants, many of them, even the resident s hardly knew William except by sight. The ‘front door’ bel jangles on the bellboard.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I‘l1l go. Jennings leaves. Elsie is sobbing aloud. Mrs Croft leans and squeezes her hand. She speaks softly but loud enough Bertha to hear her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Come on, love. No man's worth it. At any rate, he isn't.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now, Mr Probert?

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: T don’t know.. I can’t think straight...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When I leave here, I want to open a garage... Nothing gawdy. Just enough for a decent living.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: That's a funny ambition for a footman. Why aren’t you a chauffeur?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Head footman in a house like this! You could be a butler if you play your cards right. And your future’s taken care of!

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Future’s taken care of? Don't make me laugh. Another twenty years and we'll have vanished like the Dodo.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: That’s what they said in 1914 but here we still are Mary looks over at Robert, deep in thought. George follow eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're very quiet. What's your ambition?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don't think I've got one. Not now.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm saving to open a hatshop. Very exclusive, regular clients..

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, I bet you'll have regular clients. 83 INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. /SALOON. Weissman is on the telephone as Jennings crosses to the f door .

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: — don’t understand.. I thought they'd agreed it was a birdshoot.. Why is fox hunting more cinematic? Who said that?...Oh... Well, OK, if it’s a big deal, make it a fox humt but what the hell are we doing here? Jennings opens the door to the two policemen.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: We've been expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Good evening. I’m Inspector Thomp — Sylvia strides purposefully towards them, talking as she so.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You must be the police.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Just so. I’m Inspector Thomp — (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I'm Lady Sylvia MecCordle. We haven't moved him but I didn’t know whether to ring for a doctor or not. William's real one’s in London and it seemed very hard to wake him at this time of night.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: The police doctor will be here ina minute.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Good. I mean I suppose it doesn’t really matter if it’s a stroke or a heart attack or whatever but we might as well get it right.. Let’s go straight to the red drawing-room. I've got everyone rounded up there. Thompson glances at Weissman who is getting heated but Sy in control.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t mind him. He's just an American who’s staying with us. She has led them into the saloon, Jennings follows. All t upstairs members of the party are gathered in varying sta shock. Pip is in the corner, whining.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘d better tell you who we all are then we can go to bed and leave you with poor William. Is that a good plan?

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: Do we need to worry them just now, sir? We could do it in the -

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should introduce myself. I’m Inspector Thomp —

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: This is my aunt, Lady Trentham —

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Of course. The Countess of Trentham. How d‘you do? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I once had the pleasure of serving on a committee with the late Barl.. I’m only sorry we have to meet in such tragic circumstances. His pompous enunciating of Constance’s full title tells h everything about his petit bourgeois origins. She wasn’t that they were ‘meeting’ at all. Sylvia continues.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: My brother-in-law, Lord Stockbridge. My sister, Lady Stockbridge, ...my youngest sister, Lady Lavinia Meredith, and her husband, Commander Meredith. Mr Novello, I suppose you knew that without my telling you...That'1ll be all, thank you Jemnings...no, wait. Would you like to talk to any of the servants tonight, Inspector —

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Thomo —

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should see Probert. My poor husband’s valet. Would you tell him to come up, Jennings? Now, where was I? This is Mr and Mrs Nesbitt, my daughter, Miss McCordle, Lord Rupert Standish and Mr Blond... But Jennings has picked up Pip and left before she has fi the list. INT. SERVANTS’ HALL. NIGHT. They are still seated as Jennings enters. He gives Pip to odd man who takes the dog reluctantly. After a moment, Mr speaks

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Well? Don’t leave us on tenterhooks.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: The police would like to see you for a moment, Mr Probert.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Me? Why? I don’t know what I can tell them... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But he goes, with a sigh and on the edge of tears, follow sympathetic glances

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: There’s no point in the rest of you waiting up.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: What about me, Mr Jennings?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: You can leave as soon as the police release you. I dare say that'll be some time tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Until then stay in your room.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I’m not contagious, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry, Mr Jennings, but my two want to get away. So we'll be off early.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Neobody’s going anywhere... Now, those of you with remaining duties, see to them as quickly as you can. Otherwise, good night everyone. He stands aside to let them pass. We hear some exchanges the dog as they go. ‘What's going to happen to it?' ‘I sh think she'll have it put down.''Best thing for it, nasty beast.''No one can stand it except Sir William.' Alone am them, Elsie gives the animal a stroke. ‘Don't do that, de He'll have your hand off.' While this is going on, Henry hesitates, unusually ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr Weissman?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I have a confession to make.. He speaks in an American accent. INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. NIGHT. Probert walks mournfully past Weissman, still on the tele (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Warner Olund wants cast approval? Don’t make me laugh! Warner Olund doesn't have the right to approve his own toilet! INT. ELSIE’S ATTIC ROOM. NIGHT. The two young women lie, trying to sleep. Elsie’s half~pa case is visible.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry... about everything...

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Don’t feel sorry for me. Pity that poor Dorothy. She’s got all the early morning teas to do, then trays and she’s got to get Miss Isobel down to the dining-room — if she can find anything in black. I’m well out of it. She's the one who needs your sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: E should think Miss Isobel might stay in bed tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Unmarried girls don’t have breakfast trays. Not at this house. They are silent for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wish I could help.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Well, you can’t.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STOCKBRIDGE BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Renee is arranging the blanket cover on the bed. Behind h Louisa sits at the dressing-table, wiping her eyes. In an doorway, Raymond stands quite still as Robert slides his and then comes round to set the lapels and tie the sash.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Is that everything, m‘lord?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, Parks. I think we'd all better try and get some sleep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He nods at Renee and the two servants retire together, ju time to hear:

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do stop snivelling. Anyone would thing you were Italian. INT. SALOON. NIGHT. George is tidying up. He gives a cold glance over to wher is helping himself, Weissman and Novello to brandy from a Ivor remarks his expression.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: That’s the main problem. Fox hasn't got anyone. Apart from a few washed-up silent stars.. How are you getting on?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mrs Wilson's put me in the meanest room she could find.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: What did you expect? The State Bedchamber? You've made them feel like @ idiots. And they don’t like it.. Has anyone told Sylvia?

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: She‘1ll be OK. She can take a joke. Henry and Ivor exchange a look. They are not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: You‘d better be the one to say it. I should go now. Before she hears it from someone else.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: But don't tell her ‘til afterwards. I wouldn’t want to spoil it for her. Tonight of all nights. His bitter tone does not merit an answer. Henry goes to t door. Weissman follows.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait! I didn’t mean that... Henry... will I see you later? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I spent last night staring at the ceiling listening to the ramblings of a sleep-talking valet... I really think I need some rest, don’t you? He goes. Weissman turns disconsolately back into the room

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: That's not like you. Don’t tell me you're jealous. He's not in the least interested, you know. He’s just using you.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Why shouldn’t he? I’m using him. It’s a deal and I stick to my deals... I'm just surprised McCordle was right about her, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: I suppose a man knows his own wife. Besides, she has a point. Good-looking servants are the best. They don’t dine with your friends. INT. SYLVIA‘S BEDROOM. NIGHT. Sylvia, dry-eyed, lies on her bed as a sniffing Lewis goe turning off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: T’/ll say goodnight then, milady. Unless you'd like me stay with you? Lewis goes. Sylvia crosses to the window. A noise tells h Henry has come in. He stands, hesitating to speak.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What is it? Please tell me you haven't come with condolences. She looks very beautiful and he is reluctant to jeopardis fun.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No, I - I was just wondering if you wanted some company. He is Scottish again. She stares at him steadily for a mo before she answers (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well... after all, I suppose life must go on. INT, LIBRARY. NIGHT. Probert is in tears. Dexter is sympathetic. Thompson is r embarrassed,

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Try and pull yourself together, Mr Probert. I know it's hard but iff you could be patient. They’1l be here any minute...

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Couldn't I just make him comfortable, sir? Please? William, his face crushed into his tool collection, does very uncomfortable in his present position. Probert’s gri brought Ivor and Weissman to the door.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Come on, Inspector

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be wise, sir. And it's not long to wai -

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Oh, very well. I don't suppose it can do any harm. Probert takes hold of the dead man’s shoulders. Is there moment of tenderness? He gives a cry and the body falls b William's arms flop open and his head drops back, mouth g his chest is revealed. The handle of the knife protrudes it. By this time, Weissman has joined them. The five live stare at the dead one.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. Well. Now you can see why we have the rules.. Yes, Dexter? What is ite

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: Only that... there doesn’t seem to be much blood, sir. This is true and Thompson registers it. The fact is every has changed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVOR,
dialogues.text: What happens next? It’s a good question. EXT. GOSFORD PARK. EARLY MORNING. The dawn of a new day. An undecorated hearse, laden with coffin, drives away. The only sign of life is the small d watching sadly from the steps. INT. KITCHEN. EARLY MORNING. The scullery maid blows on the range fire, trying to get going. Bertha is laying out breakfast food. Ellen puts th silver entrée dishes in the warmer. Mrs Croft consults a book and writes her proposals for the day. Pip sniffs aro

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: George says Mr Novello was in on it. And Six William. He says it was a joke on Lady Sylvia but I can’t see that... The point is he’s playing a butler in the next Charlie Chan and he wanted to make it authentic.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Well, he’d better not model his performance on Mr Jennings or they'll think he’s as stiff as a board. Their laughter is stilled as Thompson‘s head looks round door. They all freeze, watching him. At first he faces th way and so the room must appear empty to him. Then Ellen and he spins round, stands and enters. Dexter is with him ‘THOMPSON Ah... Mrs Croft? I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. My name’s Inspector Thomp —

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: I’ve no time for this now. I’m just doing the breakfast...

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: It won’t take long. Is there somewhere we could go? They're still cleaning upstairs... You can manage without her, I dare say? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: If this is a pleasantry, it falls on deaf ears. The other watch him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Well.. I suppose you'd better come in here. Bertha, I’m leaving you in charge. Mind you see the menus go up on her ladyship’s tray. And get that filthy dog out of here

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. MRS CROFT’S ROOM. DAY Mxs Croft has ushered Thompson into a cosy, little room a back. He glances at an old tinted photograph of a baby in ribbons on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: My word, but you've a bonny lad there. What‘s he up to these days?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: He’s dead. Once again, his jocularity has failed. He smiles nervousl Croft is quite cold.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don‘t know what I can tell you. Shouldn't you be looking for signs of a break-in?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I gather there’s no one here who’s worked for Sir William longer than you have.. Sad day... INT. TRENTHAM BEDROOM. DAY. Mary pours tea. On the tray, as we saw in 92A is a dish o sliced cucumber

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But why one of the knives from the silver pantry? Doesn’t make sense.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes 99

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: He must have forgotten to bring one. And when you think what they have to carry about, all those gemmies and torches and skeleton keys... it’s a miracle anyone ever gets burgled at all, It's worse than shooting. Anyway, it wasn’t in the silver pantry. It's been missing since last night. Obviously, William had taken it and when the fellow surprised him, there it was on the table as handy as you like.. By the way, are any of the others getting up for breakfast? The women, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think Lady Lavinia may be.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: That settles it. Come back at half past eight and I’11l get dressed. The greatest bore of course but I don’t want to miss anything. two of the slices of cucumber, lays them on her eyes and lies back INT. ISOBEL‘S BEDROOM. DAY. Isobel, in night things, is discussing it all with Elsie now in civilian clothes.

dialogues.speaker: TSOBEL
dialogues.text: But..do they know where he got in? Did he take anything?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: No, but.. I s’pose he ran for it.. when he saw what he’d done... Are you going to be O.K.? There is a knock. Elsie ducks behind the door as it opens Dorothy .

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I wondered if you needed anything, miss...

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: If you could just get a bath ready for me...

dialogues.speaker: 94R CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The maid nods and closes the door. Isobel goes to a drawe fetches an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I came up last night I found this on my dressing-table.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: What is it? Isobel hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘This is your final warning. If I have not received an offer from your father by luncheon tomorrow, I will tell him everything. Freddie.’ Stupid idiot. At least he’s off your back. That's something. He's got no one to tell now. At least, no one who'd give him a job to shut him up

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You can’t be sure. He might tell Rupert just for the fun of it.. No @ doubt I'll hear from him soon enough. The girl shrugs, limp with misery.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I‘d better be off. I might not see you again. I’m only staying ‘til the police give the nod.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You're not in any.. difficulty, are you?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Other than having no job and no home, you mean? She relents, lightly stroking her stomach. Isobel, after has done her no harm.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. No worries there.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I was forgetting. You’re much cleverer than I was. e@  101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Renee are working on some tweeds when Robert wal carrying his employer's tweed suit.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't know why we're bothering. They're bound to cancel the shooting today.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Why? The others are silenced for a moment by his response. The

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: tT wonder what Lady Sylvia will do now

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: If I were her, I'd go to London. Set up as a glamorous widow with all the gentlemen chasing me for my money.

dialogues.speaker: C ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not me. I grew up in London.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is that where the orphanage was?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: On the edge. Isleworth.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And you don’t get homesick?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t think you're homesick if you've never had a home... Have you heard about Mr Weissman's valet?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Turns out he's a fraud. He isn't Scottish at all.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: X could have told you that. Who is he, Ww then? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A horrible thought strikes her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't think he's the murderer, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Worse than that. He's an actor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Your breakfast is ready in the Servants' Hall. After that the water should be hot enough for the baths. How long has she been listening? 97 INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. DAY. Weigsman is on the telephone which Thompson wants. Jennin with them.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I must insist..

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: I’1l have to call you back. Don’t go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: It might be more sensible if I drove you down to the village, sir.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dexter. I know what I'm doing. This really is the only one, is it? He is very important as he considers the exposed position implement.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: There’s an extension in the servants’ quarters. If you'd rather use that.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I don’t think so, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: How long are you going to be? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I have no idea.. Hello? Yes, I want to place a Trunk Call. To London. The camera moves away from him into a side corridor where stands listening. INT. GALLERY. DAY. Sarah, Renee and Barnes, carrying towels and bags are que a door.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: You listened to the Inspector on the telephone? That's disgusting

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Z couldn't help it. I was just crossing the hall.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: So? What was he saying?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Don't tell us. I don’t want to know. It's eavesdropping. But hers is not the consensus. And, at last, even Renee m admit she is curious.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, go on, then.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well. He was talking to a lawyer in London, And it sounded to me as if Sir William had decided to change his — The door opens and Isobel McCordle appears. The sight of silences them.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope we didn’t disturb you, miss.. we're ever so sorry about... Isobel just nods and hurries away. Barnes is starting to and prepare the bath, when he sees Renee looking at her w

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? Is yours ina hurry? Y'can go before me if you like. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: That's very kind. Are you sure? Won’t Commander Meredith mind?

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Sod him. Let him wait. I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Well, Sarah? Don’t keep us in suspense. Sarah continues to relay her findings as, a little way do gallery, Lewis listens with interest. 99 INT. NESBITT BEDROOM. DAY. Dorethy has brought Mabel’s breakfast tray as Freddie com finishing his tie.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Where's that George? Really, the slightest upset and these fellows go completely to pieces. How am I supposed to manage?

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: Don’t talk nonsense, You dress at home without any help.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, I certainly never get any help from you.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: Pay no attention. He’s in a bait and I know why. She gives Dorothy a friendly wink,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May passes with her box as the Merediths emerge. They sta the stairs as Barnes comes out of their room, just in tim hear what Anthony is saying.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: There is one thing: The bastard’s death may have saved my bacon.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: For God's sake be quiet. What is the matter with you? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Barnes's face assumes a look of power. He makes a V-sign Anthony’s back. As the Merediths reach the hall, Janet wa past Weissman who is on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: I know what time it is there.. Of course I want you to wake him up. How else would you suggest I talk to him..? Is that you? Well.. what did he say? Clara Bow? You're not serious. He wants to try that again! The Merediths and Janet go towards the dining-room as Art arrives from downstairs carrying an entrée dish and opens door. INT. DINING-ROOM. DAY. Rupert, Jeremy and Raymond are eating while Jennings stan Constance, choosing her food, looks up as the Merediths c The men read newspapers -

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Good morning, dear. Have you heard? Too tiresome. That frightful inspector won't let anyone leave! So we're to be treated to another day of Mr Weissman shouting down the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: TVOR
dialogues.text: He has a problem with his work in Los Angeles, I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Well, he conducts his business very oddly. Coming down stairs just now, I thought I’d been transported to a bar in Marseilles. Ivor doesn’t contradict which is the right way to handle

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gather they carted poor William off this morning. So strange and sad. Will they want to delay the funeral? I do hope it’s not next week. I was meant to be with the de 1’Isles and I was so looking forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: You must try not to upset yourself.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Anthony and Raymond laugh which earns them a black look. Weissman comes in.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: I have a call coming through and I want to take it no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Now, could I have some eggs and is there any tomato?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Of course, sir. Or perhaps you‘d like to come and choose for yourself,

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Oh? What? Cafeteria style? At this, Raymond looks up from the paper he is reading as eats

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: An Englishman is never waited on at breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Well, that’s interesting because an American is. He stands and goes to the sideboard, Thompson looks in, a gauche as ever.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Ah. Good. Tell me, will Lady Sylvia be down soon?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t think so. She has breakfast in her room and then she usually goes for a ride.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Possibly. But I doubt she will this morning. He is very assured but their expressions tell us that the not agree

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In that case.. Lady Trentham, I wonder if I might have a few words? We're in the library. Whenever you‘re ready.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: If you wish, Inspector. I’m afraid I won’t be much help... but I suppose on a day like this we all have to pull our weight. The door opens and Isobel enters. Her black frock and air sadness cast a pall on the room. Rupert jumps up to help with breakfast and Jeremy looks on. EXT. KITCHEN COURT. DAY. Robert is emerging from the laundry. In one corner of the is a game larder. Ellen is there holding some birds and B comes out with more. She nods at Robert.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Do you want a hand? He relieves her of some of the birds as Pip jumps up at t

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get away! Ugh. These smell as if they could walk in on their own. I don't know how they can eat them like that.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You heard Mr Denton's made a right chump out of Mr Jennings

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: Never mind that. What about Sir William? Apparently he wasn’t stabbed after all. I mean he was but that’s not why he died.. He was poisoned That's what killed him. The Inspector told Mrs Croft. They don’t know why the killer stabbed him as well but he must have been dead already. That's why there was no blood. Dead bodies don’t bleed, you know. Robert looks at her. She’s awfully proud to have the fact Ellen bursts out laughing. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Trust Sir William to be murdered twice. 103 INT. BUTLER'S PANTRY. DAY. George and Arthur, supervised by Jennings, clean the huge centrepiece with various tools. Among these, one jar is l poison. Probert watches but does not help

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Did he say anything about changing his will, Mr Probert?

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: Not in so many words... They all look at the valet. Clearly he does know somethin whatever he says.

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I remember him looking at a picture of her ladyship a week or two age... the one on the tallboy in his dressing-room where she’s laughing... Anyway, he said ‘her nose is due for re-setting’ and I said ‘why’ and he said ‘cos it’s about to go out of joint.’

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Except it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Why do you think he was murdered, Mr Jennings?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Don’t talk nonsense. Of course he wasn’t murdered! Not like that. Some ruffian broke in, thinking the library was empty, Sir William surprised him and paid the price for it. And very tragic it is, too.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can’t see that, Mr Jennings. I mean, I don’t think ruffians go about poisoning people and then stabbing their corpses. Apart from anything else, they’re usually in a bit of a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: What are you suggesting?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: i'm not suggesting anything. Just.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Just what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, it looks to me like Sir William was killed by someone who meant to do it. That's all. No wonder they won’t let anyone leave. Tough luck on whoever’s got any secrets to hide.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: If you can only talk rubbish, George, I suggest you don’t talk at all. George’s tone was almost jocular. Jennings’s is not. Geor catches Arthur’s eye. INT. KITCHEN. DAY. Mrs Croft is in the kitchen with the others.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Right. They've cancelled the shooting so Muggins here's got to pull a dining- xoom luncheon for God knows how many out of the hat...Is her Ladyship back yet?

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Then she'll have to take what she's given.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: I dunno.. Why would anyone want to kill Sir William? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This gets 110

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Well he wasn’t Father Christmas. the attention of all the girls which she shrugs off.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He made a few enemies in his time.

dialogues.speaker: LOTTIE
dialogues.text: What d'you mean, "enemies"? When?

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: Was this before the war? When you were a factory worker?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I was not a factory worker. I was never a factory worker. I was a cook in one of his factories. He had four, two in Isleworth and two in Twickenham. And all full of girls so you can imagine...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: But wasn’t it risky? With factory girls? Suppose they’d complained?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Who to, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: But suppose they got...?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Got what?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: I don't know why you're looking so shocked. Didn't happen that often but if it did, he'd arrange an adoption.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: But if you didn't want it adopted? Té you wanted to keep it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Then you lost your job. Kicked out. You take my word for it. He was a hard- hearted randy old sod.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: So the business with Elsie... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Just shows a leopard never changes his spots. Now come on the rest of you. Just because Sir William's died doesn't mean the clock's stopped. EXT. KITCHEN COURT. DAY. Lewis stands in the back entrance watching as her mistres canters into the yard. To the maid’s surprise, Raymond st of the shadows. He hurries to Sylvia as she dismounts. We only just hear that Sylvia is indignant. “Why shouldn’t I wanted some air.” Raymond appears to be remonstrating as the groom leads the horse away. Drawn by curiosity, Lewis nearer until she is within earshot.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: They seem to be asking a whole Lot of questions about things that can’t possibly have anything to do with William’s death... and I thought... He hesitates, noticing the approaching maid.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Never mind Lewis. The Seal of the Confessional’s got nothing on her. Has it, Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I should hope not, milady. Sylvia smiles at her indignation, addressing Raymond in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She's rather anti-Catholic... So?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It’s only that the police seem to be raking about, looking for their grubby motives, and I don't want them muddled with with silly tales from the distant past...

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: But darling, you're quite safe. I'm sure it's not illegal. Even for someone who does it as badly as you do. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She shares this with Lewis who, despite the personal mora a Carmelite nun, delights in her mistress's defeat of a m man.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I'm talking about. You say things to be funny that can‘t be unsaid...And it's not important.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: But isn't it for them to say what's important and what isn't? Yes, Lewis? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: The Inspector's been asking for you, milady, and I wanted you to know... he’s been talking to the lawyers in London...

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Has he, indeed? Well, he’1ll have to wait. I want a bath. Who’s in the firing line at the moment?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I think Lady Trentham’s in the library just now, milady.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: God help them. 106 INT. LIBRARY. DAY. Mary is by the. door. Thompson has been talking to Consta Dexter is an observer.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Bh, come in Miss Maceachhh... er.. I’m Inspector Thomp —

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: There you are, Mary. This is all too tiresome and absurd. They're making the greatest fuss over —

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind — I've some questions I‘d like to ask the young lady.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm certainly not leaving if that’s what you think. Thompson looks to Dexter. This is just the kind of woman could do without.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Would it bother you if Lady Trentham stays?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why should it?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: No reason. Only... we understand that there may have been some difficulty between the late Sir William McCordle and your employer —

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Really, this is too vulgar almost to be believed —

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t aware of that, sir. They got on well as far as I could see. Constance relaxes with a superior smile at Thompson as he about.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: So you weren’t conscious of any trouble over an allowance? An allowance, I might add, that Sir William’s death has now made secure.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What sort of an allowance would that be, six? Constance regards the girl with far more interest than sh ever done before. 107 INT. IRONING AND SEWING ROOM. DAY. Dorothy is mending a black dress. She looks up. Jennings the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
