dialogues.text: I wondered who was in here. I hope you've got enough light for that. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ii4

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Black on black, Don’t want you going blind on top of everything else.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Miss Isobel’s only got two black frocks and this one’s torn.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry the business with Elsie’s landed you with so much work. That's what you get for being so reliable. This comment, simply meant, lights a fire in Dorothy's so

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Never mind me.. Have you spoken to the police again?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I suppose they have to ask their questions.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Oh yes...

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Will they be talking to all of us?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t think so...Well, I'll leave you to it. I could ask Miss Lewis to give you a hand with that if you like... Plainly he is distracted with some sort of worry. She loo him tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: No need. It’s nearly done.. Mr Jennings.. You know I‘d say anything you want me to.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Anything at all. I don’t care what I tell them. If it'll help. You know that, don’t you? You've only to ask (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her face has never been more suffused with feeling. Jenni horrified to be confronted with this unwanted declaration Love.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: George is arranging tea on a table for Thompson, Dexter a Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: No. The point I’m trying to make is only that if he had signed it, then your position would have been quite altered.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I suppose so. But he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Precisely.. May I pour you some tea? In his brain, he is Poirot as he reaches down and picks u milk jug.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: How kind you are. But could you bear to put my milk in afterwards? She smiles, enjoying his gaffe as he clumsily replaces th and picks up the pot INT, JENNINGS’S ROOM. DAY. Gathered at the door, the servants listen to Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: t assume, by this time, you all know that Mr Denton has played a trick on us in posing as a valet. Since Sir William was aware of the plan, it is not for me, or any of you, to criticise it. However, it leaves us with a few adjustments to make for this evening. Arthur, you can take over dressing Mr Weissman. Which leaves us with the problem of Mr Novello. I really don’t want to ask Mr Probert.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don’t mind, Mr Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: No, you've got enough on your plate. Arthur's hopes are dashed again. Robert looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'll do him if you like.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: That's very generous of you, Mr Stockbridge. Otherwise, I could always do him, myself.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No, no. It’s no trouble. It’s only for a night or two.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Good. That's settled then. And I think Mr Denton can dress himself. Thank you all. You can go With Lewis muttering ‘cheeky beggar,’ they file out leavi Probert and Mrs Wilson. Jennings goes to a table where he bottle of port, a decanter, a glass and a funnel. He star open and then taste and decant the port with care.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m giving them a glass of the 1912 tonight. They’1]l need a bit of cheering up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: What about you, Mr Probert? How are you getting on? Have you made any plans yet?

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: I think I’11 go to my sister’s for a week or two. Sort something out. I've an idea she and I might open a little hotel together, well, a B and B really. We’ve talked about it and this might be the moment...

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: What? You mean you won't stay on in service? I am surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Are you Mrs Wilson? When every day one reads of another house sold as a school or demolished to make way for a hospital? Maybe Mr Probert's right. Maybe we're nothing but a race of dinosaurs... He smiles sadly at his little joke. His next words confir is the end of an era.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I too may be leaving here soon.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: IT very much hope not.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Me too. Me too.. but one is not Always in control of these things..and please don't concern yourself. Believe me, I have fully deserved whatever comes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: There are worse people than you in this house. INT. BOOT ROOM. DAY. Robert and Mary are cleaning evening shoes. They wear apr gloves.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Certainly they'll give her a good reference. Otherwise they'd have to explain why they were giving her a bad one. This makes her smile. She gets her nerve up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mx Parks -

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Robert . She is torn between pleasure at this mark of his regard a question that's been troubling her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Robert, then...it's just...when you said, last night, that you'd surprise me...you didn’t mean anything by it, did you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Why? Don’t you like surprises?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Better get cracking. I’ve got two grown men to dress. He stands, taking off the apron. Then he reaches out and soft pinch to her cheek. INT. LIBRARY/UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. DAY. Barnes, the valet, is being questioned.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (VO)
dialogues.text: ‘The bastard’s death may have saved my bacon...” What do you think he meant by that?

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Isn’t it obvious? Nothing is obvious to Thompson. ‘THOMPSON Is it?

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: Perhaps he meant that the investment Sir William had agreed would have to be paid now. By the executors or who- ‘THOMPSON What about the low shot that was fired when they were out that morning? Do you think it might have been intended for Sir William?

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Well, it nearly took his ear off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 Lil CONTINUED :

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Barnes. You‘ve been very helpful. Now, perhaps you would ask Captain Meredith to join us.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: You won't... tell him what I said, will you, Inspector — ?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Thompson. My name is Inspector Thompson. Now please fetch him down. Barnes, slightly unnerved by the anger he has released, retreats. As he closes the door, we can hear Weissman on telephone. Barnes walks past him through the hall.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: You tell me: Who is Ray Milland? O.K. but no Clara Bow, no Janet Gaynor. Tell him I’1l sign Milland if we can be free of the un-dead.. No, the study was fine. No the shoot-out in the study is fine. Yes, I'm sure. Philip may be writing it but I’m living it. The stables? Why would anyone be murdered in the stables?.. What is it with Sheehan and these fucking horses? 1l2 INT. KITCHEN CORRIDOR. EVE. George is smoking and gossiping with Arthur. Nearby May a Janet are unloading coal scuttles full of a mixture of co debris from the upstairs fires. The men make no effort to

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Pssst! They look up. Elsie is above them on the stairs. Again, s wearing her own clothes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They’11 be coming in a minute. The dressing bell’s just gone.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I'm going mad up there.. I’ve read all me magazines twice over..You couldn't pinch one from the library, could you? I don't care if it's "Horse and Hound" so long as I haven't read it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Renee, Sarah, Barnes, Mary and Robert are in the corridor carrying bits of clothing.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: What's yours wearing? We've only got dark green..

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t think mine’s bothered. She hasn’t got any black here, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Funny lot, aren't they? When you think about it. Changing for dinner on a day like this — She breaks off as Henry Denton appears, behind Elsie, on stairs. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Well. We are honoured. In case you've forgotten, this is the servants’ area. Six. Yours is on the other side of the door at the top, there. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It was just.. I wanted to explain.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No explanation’s necessary, Mr Denton, now if you’11l excuse us, we have work to do. Come on, Arthur. The footmen take the scuttles and go. The others push pas Robert is the last.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Robert, surely... It was just a laugh...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Then perhaps you'd better enjoy your laugh in the drawing~room, sir. He speaks without malice but, having spoken, he too is go Elsie speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ELSTE
dialogues.text: They're afraid you’11l repeat things. That you won’t be discreet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I’m very discreet. That’s what I’m kmown for. My discretion.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: You never give up, do you? 113 INT. GALLERY. EVE. Robert is walking down the gallery. He hears voices comin an open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You can tell him but he won't give you any money...and Mummy wouldn't pay five pounds to save me from the gallows

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: Don't keep talking as if I was enjoying this. What I wanted was a job... As Robert reaches them, by Isobel's door, they are silent after he has passed:

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: My chequebook's in the library. I'll do it after dinner. Freddie leaves as Robert is hailed by Raymond at the far the gallery. Before the valet can reach him, Raymond sees Anthony approach, looking haggard.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You look as if you've had rather a pasting.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: They kept on and on about that low shot yesterday...They wouldn't let it go. I told them it was nothing to do with me.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I'm sure you did. But another time, Anthony, try to be less greedy. Before Anthony can protest, Raymond addresses Robert who' nearly reached them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, Parks. Can you see to Mr Novelio first? I want to have a word with her ladyship. With a quick "very good, m'lord", Robert moves off. Antho been hovering, trying to get a word in.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Raymond, I don't know why you -

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I saw you. Of course it was an accident. When a man's as short as you are, it must be hard to gauge the height of the birds. But, next time, do be more careful. Please. His tone is quite dismissive as he goes into the room and the door, leaving Anthony completely humiliated in front valet. 114 INT. TRENTHAM BEDROOM, EVE. Constance is finishing her toilet with Mary’s help

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You heard he was cutting Lady Sylvia out in favour of Miss Isobel?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: That’s nothing. Wait for this...in the new will he‘d left Lady Stockbridge a hundred thousand pounds. Can you imagine? Sylvia thinks it’s a huge joke. Particularly since she won’t have to pay it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But were they...?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Well, as the saying goes, the time to make up your mind about people is never... Which reminds me, I haven't complimented you on how you managed those horrible little men in the library.. I've been thinking, Mary. You're not a trainee any more. It’s time your salary reflected your skills. We'll talk about it when we get home. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The power balance, between these two has been quite alter the last 24 hours. INT. NOVELLO BEDROOM/GALLERY. EVE. Robert crouches on the floor holding a shoe horn inside t of a pair of evening pumps as a black-socked foot enters frame and is guided into the shoe.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: He was an odd mixture. Better and worse than people thought him. It’s strange but he always seemed to me the luckiest man I'd ever met.. until now. I wonder what his star sign was Robert stands and starts to brush Ivor’s tails. He speaks without thinking.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Gemini, sir.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: How on earth do you know that? Robert picks up two shirts and some underwear .

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I think I’d better have these washed, sir. They still won’t say how long you’re going to be here. INT. STOCKBRIDGE BEDROOM. DAY. With a swift know, Renee opnes the door. A savage row is progress .

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Don't lie to me, you bitch! Suddenly they are aware of the maid. There is a frozen mo Until:

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Lady Lavinia won’t be in black, milady. So we should be all right. But we ought to get started... With a supreme effort, Raymond regains control. He walks door.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: We'll talk about it later.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: If you like. I’ve got nothing else to say.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I just want you to be honest with me.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Do you Raymond? And suppose I want you to be honest with me? INT. SERVANTS’ HALL. EVE. Barnes, Probert and the other valets and ladies’ relaxing. The boy is wiping down the table after the serv dinner. Jennings looks in.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: You don’t know where Commander Meredith might have got to, do you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Only he's never come downstairs and he's not in his room.

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Mr. Jennings, I have washed him and dressed him, If he can't find his way to the drawing room, it's not my fault.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Well, we can't delay dinner much longer .

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: Then he‘ll have to go hungry, won/’t he? The others are torn between shock and amusement. to Barnes’ chair and he savagely kicks him away. at Jennings and raises his brows. maids are Pip wanders up Probert looks  118 125 INT. STILL ROOM. NIGHT. Dorothy comes in with a tray of things for the morning. S starts. Sitting alone in the darkness, is Anthony Meredit is in evening dress.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry, sir. I didn’t mean to disturb you..

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: No, no. Please.. Come in.. I'm afraid I’m in your way..

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: No.. it’s no bother... Are you all right, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: I've been questioned by the Inspector... I feel a little bruised. He glances out of the dark window. When he speaks, he doe turn to her.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why is it, would you say, that some people seem to get whatever they want in life? Everything they touch turns to gold. While others can strive and Strive... and have nothing. He looks across with a face devoid of hope. Still she sta listening.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wonder... Do you believe in luck? Do you think some men are lucky and some just.. aren’t, and there’s nothing they can do about it? Dorothy ponders for a moment. Of course he has asked her question.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I believe in love. Not just getting it.. giving it. I think as long as you can love somebody, whether or not they love you, then it’s worth it. For a moment the defeated duo look at each other. The Mas the Maid. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Good answer... I'd better go up. They must have finished dinner by now... Thank you... He is gone. 113 INT. DRAWING-ROOM. NIGHT. The mood is subdued. Constance, Louisa, Lavinia and Raymo playing bridge. George takes the coffee tray to Isobel an Rupert at one end of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I£ only I could believe you...

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: I wish you would. George moves on to Sylvia who is reading a magazine. Henr near her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There’s an article in that on Blenheim. Are you interested in e@ houses?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Not very. She answers without looking up. Behind, Ivor plays “Keep Home Fires Burning”.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: Oh, how that tune used to make me cry. Turning to say this, her eye is caught by Isobel handing something to Freddie by the door. Louisa speaks from the table as she takes a drink from Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Couldn't you play something a little more cheerful, Mr Novello? We‘re all quite emotional enough as it is. Ivor obliges, moving into waltz time. Weissman leans over as Jennings arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: That's if they have emotions. @ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: You're too hard on them. Don‘t you agree, Jennings?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Six?

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Mr Weissman is criticising the aristocracy but he wouldn't if he’d been here during the war, would he, instead of lazing about in California? We admired their stiff upper lips then, didn’t we, Jennings?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Much more than I realised at the time, sir. His voice is choked with emotion. Surprised at the intens has provoked, Ivor nods at Weissman with raised brows.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: See. Mabel and Freddie are talking softly as Jennings arrives the drinks table

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: What was Isobel giving you just now?

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you mean. She holds out her hand as Anthony enters. Sylvia looks up returns to her reading

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Anthony. There you are. Where have you been? You're too late for dinner but I’m sure they can bring you a tray if you're hungry.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t want anything, thank you...

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Isobel, come and take over will you? As she goes to Anthony, Henry jumps up. George has tipped coffee pot over him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I do apologise, six. I can’t think how that happened. INT, SERVANTS’ HALL. NIGHT. A wireless plays music. Arthur is practising dance steps Ellen. Mary and Robert listen while Dexter drinks tea. Le mends lace, Sarah and Renee sew by the fire. Bertha is sc out scallop shells with a wire brush. Barnes reads. Probe a leather collar box and he is sorting collars imto sizes hovers.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: What‘’s the point of that, Mr Probert? Won’t it all be chucked out?

dialogues.speaker: PROBERT
dialogues.text: I'll know I’ve left it in good order. Tt’s all I can do for him now.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Leave him alone. Barnes glances at Bertha scraping away as Mrs Wilson look

dialogues.speaker: BARNES
dialogues.text: I wish you’d stop that. It's making my teeth go funny.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: Iocan’t help that. Put that dog out someone .

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Constable, I’m glad I've caught you. I’m assuming that the Inspector won't keep everyone beyond tomorrow but IT thought I’d check with you.

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: Well.we haven't spoken to all the serv Thompson looks in.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: There you are, Dexter. Come along. We're going home. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: I was just asking the Constable how long our guests will be staying. Only Mrs Croft has the meals to arrange and one of the housemaids is anxious to get away

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Oh that'll be all right. I'm not bothered about the servants. Just the people who might have had a real connection with the dead man. The others watch Mrs Wilson. They are interested to see h answers.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: I see... yes, I suppose you would be.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Still, I think they can go home. We've got their addresses after all. Dexter will come in tomorrow to confirm it. But don't worry...It won't end there. I'll £ind him. Whoever he is. I always do. He leaves. Before Dexter can follow him, Bertha speaks.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: Does he? Dexter hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: It's been known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George enters. There is a sound of scuffling. He turns on light. Bertha is on the floor with Jeremy Blond. In silen latter stands, tucking in his shirt and fastening his fly buttons. He refuses to make the smallest gesture of embarrassment .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right. Beg your pardon, sir. I was just collecting Mr Nesbitt's shirts.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Without a word, Jeremy leaves. George looks at Bertha. Af moment, they both dissolve into giggles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You naughty, naughty girl.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: Poor bloke. We were in ‘ere on Tuesday and one of the visiting maids walked in. He must think I did it on purpose. She goes to the door as George is taking some shirts from the great cupboards.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You won't tell, will you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: twon't tell. But you're lucky your're in the kitchen and not under Mrs Wilson. She'd sniff it out without any help from me. 124 INT. SYLVIA’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. Lewis is settling Sylvia for the night when they both hea door opening. Henry stands there. Sylvia continues to rea book. Lewis takes her cue.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Will that be all, milady?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Don’t go, Lewis. There’s no need. She ignores the hapless Henry until he is provoked into something Like anger.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: T just don’t see what's changed! Sylvia at last takes her eyes from the page.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Then you are a fool as well as a liar .

dialogues.speaker: INT. STILL ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dorothy is wiping the surfaces at the end of a long day. Wilson looks in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Quickly. I need your help. INT. SERVANTS‘ HALL. NIGHT. The room is dark. The sole occupant, Jennings, is slumped the central table. A glass and an empty bottle are near h hand. Mrs Wilson and Dorothy hurry in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: We have to get him to his own room. Nobody must see him like this.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Don't you worry, Mr Jennings. Everything’s all right. With a massive effort, they get him upright and half walk drag him to the door. INT. JENNING’S BEDROOM. NIGHT The two women, seriously disshevelled by their efforts, s in with the nearly unconscious man. They dump him onto th and set to work.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Take his shoes off while I loosen his collar.. There. Now go to bed and don’t say anything about this. Derothy kisses her finger and secretly presses it to the forehead of the sleeping man. INT. ELSIE’S ATTIC ROOM. NIGHT. Mary is in bed. Her valise is open on the chest. She is w while Elsie packs a battered case which is on her bed.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: So George got his own back on Mr Denton. Good.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He gave me the creeps. There is a light knock and Isobel enters.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You're still here then. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Only ‘till the morning. Isobel nods. She hesitates to speak looking at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't worry about her. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I...Z thought you'd like to know that Mabel Nesbitt left this on my dressing~ table...I think it's over She hands Elsie an envelope with the torn cheque and a no Elsie nods, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I just wanted to be certain...You never did speak to Daddy about it that night? About Freddie and everything?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I told you. I never had a moment...

dialogues.speaker: TSOBEL
dialogues.text: No, I'm glad...that he wasn't bothered with it before he...Well...I suppose I'd better go...Good luck, Elsie.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Good luck to you, Miss. A thoughtful Elsie holds the door as Tsobel slips away. M looks curiously at her companion.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't ask.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you think Sir William was in love with you?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Nah, I was a bit of fun, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: dn‘t love him but.. I didn’t mind I liked the way he’d talk. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I di ‘im... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He only talked to me ‘cos he was sick of ‘er but IT liked it. He used to tell me I could be anything I wanted... if I wanted it enough...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're not sorry, then. Even with the way it’s turned out.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: No. I'm not sorry... it’s time for a change. Who knows? Might be the making of me. What was it ‘e used to say? Carpe Diem. Sieze the day. This strikes a chord with Mary. She gets out of bed and p her dressing-gown.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s up? What have I said? Where are you off to? INT. ROBERT'S ATTIC ROOM. NIGHT. Robert is sitting on his bed. The door opens. It is Mary. dumbfounded

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? But she is silent, trembling in her sad little, candlewic dressing~gown.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'd better get back to your room. They mustn’t find you up here. For a moment, she cannot decide if she wants to put the n question.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You didn’t really dislike him, did you..? Not really..? At least... not enough to kill him.. But he says nothing. Her eyes fill.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can’t have! You didn't know him! You'd have to hate him and why would you?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is so desperate that he should not be guilty. Robert’ meet hers

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Can’t a man hate his own father? Mary could scarcely be more shocked if he’d hit her. She at him,

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir William McCordle was my father. He didn't know it. But he was.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But.. you said you were an orphan.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I said I grew up in an orphanage. Now he decides to tell a little bit of the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not long before I left, a group of us got into the Warden’s office one night. We unpicked the lock and took out our files. It was a prank, really. I didn’t expect any shocking discoveries, Just a birth certificate with my mother's name and ‘father unknown'. This picture was with it. She takes the picture and studies it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But how did Sir William come into it?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: They had my admission form. I was two days old. Guess who brought me to the door .

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But that doesn’t mean —

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yes it does. After that, I found out. She was a factory worker.She wasn't the only one.. either the authorities didn't know or they didn’t want to know.They took the babies and they took his donations.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I asked them once. She died. When I was little.. I always say she died of a broken heart but it was probably cyrrosis of the liver... “Broken heart” sounds a bit nicer, don‘t you think?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is that why you took the job with Lord Stockbridge? To get to Sir William? To poison him?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I didn't poison him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I didn't poison him. ( This is wonderful news.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But then you didn't kill him...Tell me you didn't stab him either. At this he is silent. Nevertheless it is still good news.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you didn't. I'm sure you didn't...Even if you did, that didn't kill him. And whoever did it knew that. No one could stab a corpse and not know it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Is that right? When did you last stab a corpse?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But...who really murdered him?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: T don‘t know. And I don’t care. With those words, she knows her theory is correct. The mo altered between them. He comes to her. When he takes her ad arms, she does not resist his kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've been wanting to do that since I first set eyes on you. INT. HENRY’S BEDROOM. EARLY MORNING. The morning light glints through the drawn curtains. The opens softly and Janet, the little housemaid, wearing a l ‘kneeling’ apron and carrying a bucket of coal tiptoes to fire. She puts on thick, felt gloves and sets to work.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (VO)
dialogues.text: Who is it? The voice startles the girl. She turns. He sits up.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: I‘m ever so sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Sorry for what?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to get the fire lit without waking you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why does everyone treat me as if I was just one of the guests? I spent half the week downstairs with you all.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: But you can’t be on both teams at once, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: More's the pity. He is sad as he watches her light the fire. With a nervou she hurries out. INT. MRS CROFT’S ROOM. DAY. Mrs Croft is at her desk. Bertha looks in.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: It's official. They're off after breakfast. The constable told me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: Well, thank God for that. What about him? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 130 a Cfo i3l 137

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Together they look through the glass of Mrs Croft's offic where Dexter hovers in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: He's going too. Soon as he's seen Mr Jennings... Did you tell them any of that stuff in the end?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: I did not. I’m sorry if I shock you, Bertha, but the plain fact is he only got what he deserved. There. I’ve said ait.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: I can’t stop thinking about those girls..the ones that got...you know...

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: I don't wonder at it. The way you carry on. Just make sure it never happens to you, my girl. She is severe but not unkind. Tt is clear that she knows Bertha is up to.

dialogues.speaker: BERTHA
dialogues.text: But the ones who kept their babies...who wouldn't give them up...Didn't he ever let them back?

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: There was one time... but.. that was because her baby died... But Mrs Croft has said enough. With a sigh, she stands. I the beginning of a new working day.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Enough of this gabbing. Let’s get started. She moves away from her desk, revealing once more the poi little tinted photograph of the long-dead, unforgotten in INT. JENNINGS’S ROOM. DAY. Jennings is bringing his cellar list up to date. Dexter l in,

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: We/ll be in touch. From now on we'll be working from the station. See if we can't manage things better from there.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: What about the poison? Haven't you traced that, at least?

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: Hardly. This house is a poisoner's paradise. We found the stuff in practically every room. And unfortunately no one’s got a police record. ‘Cept you, of course He chuckles but Jennings freezes. His worst nightmares ar flesh.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: What do you intend to do about it? Dexter is genuinely surprised. He‘d only been joshing.

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: What? You mean — ? Nothing. What should we do?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER
dialogues.text: Nah. I had a brother who was a conscientious objector. He did a bit of time, too. Why? Don’t they know? Haven't you told them? Jennings just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DEXTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: T should forget about it. The war’s over. And you’re too old to fight in another one. Right. Better be off. ‘Bye then, Mr Jennings. He is gone. A huge, leaden weight slides off the butler’s shoulders.  132 133 139 INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. DAY. George is carrying the Nesbitts’ cases down the stairs. T follow, talking softly.

dialogues.speaker: FREDDIE
dialogues.text: You're a fool. Now what are we supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: Oh Freddie. Do try not to be so frightened all the time. They move off camera as Arthur, climbing the stairs, take to Barnes whe is carrying luggage down with Sarah. Behind are the Merediths.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.. I got to the door of the library and then I just thought... what‘s the point..? The truth is, I've made rather a fool of myself

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Maybe... but you’re my fool. She squeezes his arm as they turn into the entrance hall Jennings is seeing out the Nesbitts and Weissman is on th telephone.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean the butler didn’t do it? If he didn’t do it, then who the hell did? Jennings, both wounded and mortally offended by this, hol door for Anthony and Lavinia as the servants take out the things.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Are you sure? When? Check it and call me in London. Absently, he gives a smile to Jennings but the butler onl returns a hurt glare as Renee passes by. INT. STOCKBRIDGE'S BEDROOM. DAY. Renee enters. Raymond stands by the window. Louisa reads newspaper. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, milady, but what am I to do about the packing?Only you said last night that you might be staying on for a while... Louisa does not answer but instead looks enquiringly at R

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It's not my decision.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: On the contrary. It is entirely your decision, She holds his gaze. No arm wrestlers in a dock-side pub c more absorbed in their contest of wills. It is Raymond's knuckles which hit the tables first.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Don't say it if you don't mean it. RAYMOND e@ IZ do mean it...I won't mention the subject again. His capitulation is clear: He has purchased a scandal-fre at the cost of never challenging his wife again over the William question, She is content.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Then thank you, yes, do pack. I'll be leaving with his lordship after all. 134 INT. UPSTAIRS HALL AND CORRIDOR. DAY. On the stairs, Jeremy and Rupert whisper behind Arthur wh carries their cases.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Did you ask her?

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: Not quite

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: On reflection, I think it's just as well. e (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: According to the servants' hall gossip, she doesn't get any of the capital until her mother dies and if that's true it's too long to wait. You can do better. Rupert opens his mouth to answer but before he can, Isobe round the corner at the base of the staircase. She must h heard. She looks carefully at Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Have you checked your room? You mustn’t leave anything behind

dialogues.speaker: INT. ELSIE'S ATTIC ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Elsie lies stretched out on her bed, reading a film magaz She is smoking. The door opens. It is Mrs Wilson. Elsie g over and then back to her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: You know smoking up here is strictly forbidden. Elsie takes a long, deep drag on her cigarette and blows ring.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The other guests aren’t leaving by train so the luggage car can run you to the station. You'll find it outside the front.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: And that’s it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Let us know where you would like your reference to be sent. She is about to go as Elsie stands.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean nothing to him, you know. It was never serious...

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Does it matter?  142 136 EXT. GOSFORD PARK. DAY. George and Arthur are loading the last things into Jeremy roadster. Off screen, the two young men and Isobel loiter vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL, (VO)
dialogues.text: No, I shouldn’t think of it. I know how your father hates it when someone's been in the papers and I'm afraid I’m bound to be.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT, (VO)
dialogues.text: What about January? When things have cooled off a bit. The footmen come round to open the doors making them visi

dialogues.speaker: TSOBEL
dialogues.text: Let’s play it by ear, shall we? Well, goodbye. And thank you so much for coming. I am sorry it’s all been so., dramatic. Before Rupert can answer, she has gone, across the gravel towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: That was pretty painless.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: No it wasn't. In answer to Jeremy’s curious stare, Rupert follows Isobe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not for me, anyway. Amazing as it would be to Isobel, Rupert is in love with But it will do no good for she will never believe him now a sigh, he climbs into the car and starts it up. 137 INT. HALL/EXT. GOSFORD PARK. DAY. As Jennings waits by the door, Weissman and Ivor cross th dressed for travel.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Why? What’s happened? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: They've brought in Sidney Kent as the new President of the Studio. He likes the Chan series and he’s over-ruled Sheehan. The deadline’s been dropped and I can cast whomever I like. Panic over.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: Just like that? What a weird and savage world you Live in. They have come out through the front door. Henry is alrea their car. Pip sits alone and unloved on the steps watchi at the far side of the house, Elsie’s case is being put i of the estate vehicles. Mary is with her

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good luck. Don't do anything I wouldn't do.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Well, at least I know now that gives me some room for manocevre. ro To their surprise, Weissman hails her from across the for

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Hey! You there! Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: To the station.

dialogues.speaker: WEISSMAN
dialogues.text: Do you want a ride to London? When she compares the battered farm car to the gleaming l the choice is easy.

dialogues.speaker: ELSIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Why not? With a laugh, she siezes her case and runs to the car. As climbs in she is distracted for a moment. The head of the unloved Pip makes a brief appearance from the top of her all. Firmly, she pushes him back and climbs into the car. turns to see a look of disapproval on Jennings’s face, th can't know if he saw the dog. Maybe he did.

dialogues.speaker: IVOR
dialogues.text: ( ‘ I know, Jennings... but doesn't every creature deserve a second chance? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With a wave, he too climbs in and the vehicle moves off. 138 INT, TRENTHAM BEDROOM. DAY. Mary is putting the last things in the suitcase, each car encased in a layer of tissue paper with crushed tissue to the folds. Constance is in travelling clothes. She addres envelopes, seals them and leaves them on the dressing-tab

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Honestly, it's getting so expensive. By the time one does Jennings, and leaves something for the housemaids, one might as well have taken a suite at the Ritz. Tell me, what happened to William’s little maid. I never saw her again after that dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Pity really. I should have thought it was a good idea to have someone in the house who's actually sorry he’s dead. @ Sylvia looks round the door. If she heard she doesn’t sho Or, possibly, care.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are, dear. Did you have a nice ride?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: i feel rather guilty. Apparently they've all gone. Except for you and Louisa.. but there’s no hurry. Why not stay for luncheon?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: T’d better be off. Leave you in peace. Sylvia, once more in jodphurs, sits on the bed near where is packing, idly fingering a garment that is waiting to g the case. Constance is applying lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now you will telephone with the funeral plans? SYLVIA e You don’t have to come if it’s a bore. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Of course I'm coming... Have you decided what you're going to do?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Not really. I thought I might travel for a bit.. Amelia Northbrook rang up this morning. They’ve taken a house in Alexandria for the winter and she’s given me an open invitation...

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: That sounds lovely... and what about Gosford? Sylvia shrugs, holding a scarf against herself to test th colour.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know., William loved it, of course. Fiddling with his guns... Tramping over his acres... not killing his pheasants.. Poor William. She finds another scarf better suited to her colouring. Constance nods, carefully patting her lipstick dry with a handkerchief she keeps for that purpose.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Yes. Poor, dear William. We shall miss him.. So will you keep the place going, then?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It's so difficult.. I mean, these days, does one want the bother? It’s not a family house, after all. Just bought with William’s ill-gotten gains. I suppose I could shut it up for now and then make a decision when my head stops spinning.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE,
dialogues.text: Mrs Wilson can manage things until you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Oh yes, she could manage things. Let's not worry about that.. No doubt she’1l sieze the chance to get rid of the wretched Mrs Croft.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Why are they such enemies?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Who knows? Something to do with when they were both in one of William's sweat shops. Mrs Croft was the senior then. She was a cook when Mrs Wilson was a lowly factory worker. Now she’s gone up in the world and Mrs Croft can't adjust. Usual rubbish...

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Was there ever a Mister Wilson? I Can't imagine it.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Nor me. Although, funnily enough, I think there must have been.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Really? You amaze me.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, unless she just changed her name...I know she had a different one when she first worked for William. Parker or Parkis or something. A missing piece has fallen into place for Mary. She shuts case and stands.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I‘ll go down and fetch the jewels

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Tell Merriman to come and get the bags. INT. MRS WILSON’S ROOM. DAY. Mrs Wilson is making notes in a linen book. She puts down pen.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're busy.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: No, no. I was just checking the linen rotation. If I left it to the maids, the same twenty sheets would be used until they fell into rags... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She smiles her professional smile as she waits for what M to say.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why did you do it? Mrs Wilson stands and strolls over to the window, watchin activity outside.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did you know it was him? Was it the name? Or did you see the photograph in his room?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Ah. The photograph... What a miracle it survived...His mother put it in his blanket...She just wanted to feel he had something of hers, I suppose...What does he think happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They said she died. Just after he was born.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Well she didn't die. She gave him up. He promised the boy would be adopted. Said he knew the family. Turns out we all clung to that dream - all us girls. A better chance in life for our children and all the time he was dumping them - his children - in some godforsaken place ~- and I believed him. Maybe it was easier that way. My sister has always hated me for it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Your sister?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Mrs Croft. Didn't you know? She kept hers - not many did, and it was very hard for her. She lost her job and then he died anyway - Scarlet Fever.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But how did you know Robert meant to harm his father? Mrs Wilson looks at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There’s a Mary. 148 (2)

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: What gift do you think a good servant has that marks them apart from the rest? It is the gift of anticipation. And I am a good servant. I am better than good, I am the best, the perfect servant. I know when they are hungry so the food is waiting. I know when they will be tired so the bed is made and warmed. I know before they know it themselves.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Will you ever tell him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Why would I? What purpose could it possibly serve?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What if they find out?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: It’s not a crime to stab a dead man. They can never touch him, That's what's important now, his life.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And your life? Isn't that important?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Didn't you hear me? I'm the Perfect Servant. I have no life. slight knock and George’s head appears.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Her ladyship’s leaving now, miss.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON
dialogues.text: Thank you, George. You should go now, Miss Trentham. EXT. GOSFORD PARK. DAY. He speaks to In the foreground, Robert and a chauffeur are strapping l to the rack at the rear of a car. Raymond and Louisa stan Sylvia. The sisters are quite cool. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA, (VO)
dialogues.text: Well, goodbye. Let us know if there's anything we can do.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Are you going away at all?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISA
dialogues.text: Not once the shooting’s finished. I think we’ll just put our feet up. Won’t we, Raymond? She glances at her husband. She is prepared to live in pe he is. Nearby stands Constance’s car. Merriman puts in the lugga Mary comes out, with dressing case and valise, as the Stockbridges get in. Robert strolls over as Renee tucks i Louisa and climbs into the front seat. The rear dicky is for Robert.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Goodbye then.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Goodbye. She hesitates, trying to think of what to say, but he tou her cheek. ROBERT (CONT’D) It’s all right.. It's over. It’s finished. Raymond opens his car door impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Parks, for heaven's sake, can we get started? With a smile, Robert crosses to the car, jumps in and the away with Sylvia waving them off. As Mary walks over to g Merriman her valise, she sees Mrs Wilson’s face, pressed the basement window watching the dark head in the dicky a moves off down the drive. Merriman takes the case and str on.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMAN
dialogues.text: Crikey. Well. We've got something to write home about. Constance, in travelling clothes, emerges from the front (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I've signed the book, though some of the others seem to have missed it. Goodbye dear. Chin up. She kisses her niece and climbs into the car. Mary leans straightens the rug on Constance’s knees, finds the baske the thermos and sandwich box and places it nearby. Clearl while, in one way, everything has changed, in another, no has. Mary climbs in and with a wave to Sylvia, the car moves o

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Heavens, what a relief to be going. It'll take me a month to recover. 141 INT. DOWNSTAIRS HALL. DAY. Mrs Wilson is on her way past the servants’ hall when she catches sight of Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Have they gone? MRS WILSON r ) Yes. I’1l ask her ladyship if we’re to lay luncheon in the dining-room. She may want a tray upstairs. Dorothy nods but Mrs Wilson hasn’t quite finished. She lo her voice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for your help last night, Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You don’t have to thank me. You know I'd kill for him if I had to. This naked exposure of feeling is rather more than Mrs Wi bargained for. She recoils slightly and, in doing so, mov until she can see into the servants’ hall. George, Arthur several others, headed by Mrs Croft, are sitting, doing v tasks. One by one they look up at the house-keeper but Mr is their spokesman.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CROFT
dialogues.text: What is it, Jane? Did you think you were the only one who could? e

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her voice is quite gentle. She has forgiven her sibling. guess the danger when she heard Robert’s name at supper? rate, she and they know now. INT. CONSTANCE’S CAR. DAY. Constance has relaxed a little. She winds down the window divides her own seat from the two servants and speaks to maid.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Mary, do you suppose, if there’s a trial, I’d have to testify? Or you? I do hope not. I can’t think of anything worse. Imagine a man being hanged because of something one said in a courtroom... Mary looks at the countryside flashing by, thinking for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I know... and what purpose could it possibly serve? Constance looks at her maid curiously for a moment before winds up the window. As the final credits roll, Constance picks up the thermos the seat beside her and feebly tries to open it. Once aga fails and reaches for the speaking tube. But this time, i she replaces the tube and tries the top of the thermos ag With the tiniest bit of effort she opens it, pours hersel drink and, with something like a sense of achievement, sh back.
